div3.head:
The war in Virginia.
Exciting Scenes in the West.
[Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.]
div3.p: The 3d and 4th days of June, 1861, will never be forgotten by the people of Monroe county until the last child now living shall have deceased to the grave.

The morning of the 3d of June dawned upon the busy multitudes engaged, as is their custom at this season of the year, in their industrial pursuits.
Eleven o'clock had arrived; unless as the lightning's flash, all Centreville was aroused.
Two messengers, with foaming and planting steeds, arrived, with intelligence that the Northern barbarians had crossed the Ohio river, and were moving up the Kanawha Valley.
Instantly, parties of both old and young vied with each other in spreading far and wide the intelligence.

Various reports, apparently well authenticated, were received, to the effect that not only were Northern troops moving up the Kenawha Valley, but that an advance force had reached Fayette' Court-House, and also that a body of 1,200 mounted troops had entered the State near Wheeling, and laid in waste the towns of Sottonville and Summersville and were making their way to Lewisburg.
Intelligence also reached this place about 12 o'clock at night, that 3,000 invaders were within twenty miles of Lewisburg.

Nothing can exceed the readiness with which the citizens of Monroe county responded to the call to arms.
Hundreds and hundreds of her inhabitants, of all ages and sexes, were moving, some conveying the intelligence, some preparing arms and ammunition, while the ladies were preparing food and clothing for their husbands and sons.

Large volunteer companies, composed of men from over sixty to the mere stripling, thaw themselves together hastily, armed to the teeth, with every conceivable death-dealing implement, from the old huntsman's rifle to the dirk and spear, and left during the night for the scene of action.
Orders were insured for the militia to arm themselves with soft and every available weapon, in the ab of the rifle, together with axes to fell ber in the mountain passes to impede the progress of the invaders.

The morning of the 4th of June saw all Monroe astir, men and women, old and infirm, many of whom had but seldom been from pre of late, were seen making their way to headquarters from every point of the compass they came.
Crowd succeeding crowd, all crushing eagerly to the defence of their country, no one ever dreamed of the patriotic layer which manifested itself in the outburst of enthusiasm of the people of old Monroe this day.

The time for leaving had arrived, the line was formed, the men were generally armed with their trusty old rifles, a few with double-barreled shot guns, one man with a pitchfork a goodly number of bowie knives and revolvers were seen protruding from the bosoms of the brave soldiers.
The field officers, in part, were in their saddles.
"Mark time," was heard along the line.
At this moment a large guerilla company returned with information that no enemy was approaching.
The brigade dis-banded and returned to their homes.
Many were evidently dissatisfied that they could not proceed.

Nearly all the men had left for their homes.
Three o'clock had arrived, when suddenly in the distance was heard the roar of fire-arms, as though two armies were in deadly strife.

The sound was not that of the cannon, nor was it the sharp crack of the rifle.
What was it?
At this moment troops were seen descending the Garven Heights, firing salute after salute.
It turned out to be a large force from the adjacent county of Mercer, who, on hearing of the reported invasion of Virginia soil, had seized their ounce-ball rifles, and hastened to the defence of their country, without stopping to get a change of clothes.--Some started from their corn fields, not waiting to take leave of their families.

Our community was thrown into great excitement last night, by the arrival of a rumor, sent over from the town of Buchanan, with a dispatch to Capt. Paschal Buford, that a large party of Northern Rangers, proceeding from the direction of the Kanawha Valley, were invading the Northwest counties beyond the Blue Ridge, that they were burning and devastating the whole country along their much land that already they had burned Lewisburg and the White Sulphur Springs, and were proceeding in the direction of Fincastle, in Botetourt county.

It was night when this intelligence reached our county, and though the night was dark and the rain falling in torrents, our citizen solitary turned out promptly to the appointed place of rendezvous, (Buford's Depot,) dispatching messengers in all directions during the night, to give notice of the approach of the invading enemy.
At an early hour this morning hundreds of our citizens had repaired to the rendezvous, determined to welcome the invader from every mountain gorge with a murderous salute from our unerring rifles in the hands of our mountain boys, who know how to handle them with telling effect.
But, soon after our arrival at the place of rendezvous, a party of our citizens returned, who had during the night crossed the Blue Ridge and proceeded as far as Fincastle and Buchanan, where they satisfied themselves that there was no foe nearer than the Kanawha Valley, upon which General McClellan was marching with a large body of troops from Ohio, which had produced the wildest excitement all the way from here to the Kanawha Valley.
Many of the Secession citizens were leaving the Kanawha and retiring further into the interior of the State.
The Bank at Charleston, with all its effects, has been removed to Lewisburg in consequence of the invasion.

A gentleman, formerly a resident of this county, but for several years has resided in Kanawha, has just arrived here to-day, and says that between the White Sulphur Springs and the Falls of Kanawha he met hundreds of armed citizens from Greenbrier and the adjacent counties, who had turned out almost en masse to meet the invaders, swearing in their wrath that they would never return to their homes till-these hireling mercenaries of the despots at Washington were driven beyond the River Ohio.
We have written you what has come under our own observation and obtained from the most reliable sources.

div3.head:
From Aquia Creek.
[Special Correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
We had another alarm yesterday about 3 o'clock P. M., caused by the report of a cannon followed by a volley of musketry in the direction of the battery on the Creek.
Hastily getting under arms we marched thither, when we found that the cannon had been fired as an alarm signal, intelligence having been received that the enemy were landing at a point some three miles above.
Embarking on a boat at the landing, we rowed ourselves across to Shams' Point opposite.
We were followed by several companies encamped near here.
Landing, we found a company of gallant Tennesseans and Captain Lewis' company, of Fredericksburg, drawn up ready for moving.
The order being given, we commenced the line of march to intercept the enemy, but, having proceeded some half mile in the interior, we heard that the alarm had been a false one, from the Blues who were returning; they, being quartered on the point, had been able to get in advance of us, preceding us, led by their gallant young commander, O. J. Wise, by some half hour's time.
I noticed at his post as Lieutenant our old friend Charley Bigger, who, though of small stature, is one of the bravest of the brave in his time-honored old corps indeed, the best articles are oftenest put up in the smallest parcels.
The musketry report mentioned above was caused by the discharge, by a squad of Tennesseans, of their muskets which had been exposed loaded to the weather, to test them, fearing they would not go off. Recrossing the creek, we were enlivened by the singing of various snatches of songs, and some lines improvised for the occasion by our old friend Mc. "of ours." They were as nearly as I recollect as follows:

lg.l: The guns were booming loudly,
The "F's" were all in line--
The gallant Blues marched proudly,
And warlike Walker was in time.
"Sic Semper Tyrannis" be our motto evermore,
While one determined man is left on old Virginia a shore;
Old Lincoln's chains may rattle,
But their sound can here appal
The "F's" who march to battle--
Fortney must be free or fall,
We've a sigh for those who love us
And a sigh for those who love us,
We care not what our fats is,
While our free flag floats above us.

div3.p:
There was a detail of 50 men from our company last night for picket guard along the river.
The night passed off without an alarm, though a large steamer and a small tug were bring off in the channel, with bright lights during the night; the former was sufficiently near --some two or three miles--to have reached us with their guns while recrossing the creek in the afternoon, but she feared the fires from our batteries in return, I presume, It is now thought we will be here indefinitely, General Holmes having expressed his intention of keeping a large force here.

div3.head:
From Harper's Ferry.
[Special Correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
We have daily information of the numbers and approach of our enemies, who are still hovering around, but as yet dare not attack us; and when they do so, they will find all their plans well known, and they themselves will be overwhelmingly defeated.
The health of the troops generally is very good, and it is universally remarked, that never before were so many orderly and well-behaved soldiers collected together into one place.
We hear no complaints of outrages committed — of robberies and insults to private citizens.
What a contrast between our troops and the mercenary hordes of Lincoln ! The coming of the former is gladly welcomed as a protection to persons and property; the coming of the latter is (eared and abhorred, as they plunder and destroy the property of peaceful citizens, and then insult them and their families.

The Maryland Heights are still in possession of the Kentuckian, Baltimoreans, and the "Montgomery (Va.) Fencibles," who intend to maintain and hold the position until ordered away by General Johnston.
The "Montgomery Fencibles" went upon the Heights a little upwards of two weeks ago, without axe or saw, into a wilderness of trees and undergrowth, and now they have erected a fort, two hundred feet long for their protection and comfort, and have cleared off a beautiful parade-ground; thus having done what few companies would have done, and we hope they will receive due credit for their energy and industry.
They call their palisade "Fort Montgomery," after the county from which they come.

A member of the Fort Louis Volunteers (Akeis by name,) was accidentally shot and instantly killed on Monday last, by the accidental discharge of a musket in the hands of a fellow-soldier.
He was buried on Monday evening in the Catholic grave-yard by his regiment, with military honors.
There are several reports of skirmishes in the country round about, but we give little credit to reports now-a-days.

The United States Post-Office at this place is closed.
We now receive our mails through the Quartermaster, who is acting as Confederate Postmaster.
It has been raining for several days, and those of our troops who are houseless and tentless must be literally enjoying the hard part of a soldier's life.

Since my last communication, things at the Ferry have been tolerably quiet.
The weather has been so bad for several days that there is but little stirring on the streets.
Drilling has stopped for a season.

Federal troops are concentrating at Grafton and along the line of the Baltimore and Ohio R. R.
The number is differently reported — from ten to twenty thousand.
Whether they will attack Harper's Ferry, or march into Western Virginia, is only material for speculation.
I was at headquarters on Tuesday evening, when an officer remarked to me that we would have a fight in ten days. I presume from that that Uncle Sam will soon be on us. He will probably march simultaneously from three different points — Washington or Baltimore, Hagerstown and Gratton.
We are prepared to give him a warm reception, and will certainly entertain him as well as possible.
On the evening of the 4th instant, the West Augusta Guards marched with sealed orders.

Capt. Freeman's company of Artillery from Culpeper county, was below the minimum, (fifty men rank and file,) and was consequently disbanded.
The arms and equipments were handed over to the Newtown company from Frederick.
The camp is in a healthy condition.

The trains on the Baltimore and Ohio R. R.
have been stopped.
The roads are guarded strictly, and no one is permitted either to enter or to leave the place without proper credentials.
Every stranger is arrested and confined until, upon examination, he is found to be of the "right stripe." Several persons attempted to enter a few nights ago by coming up the river in a boat.
They were detected and lodged in the guard-house.

div3.head:
From Norfolk.
[Special Correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
The steamer Harriet Lane, in the engagement of Wednesday, is reported to have been damaged quite seriously.
Several men were killed and a number wounded.
She captured a small sloop on Thursday and took possession of her cargo, consisting of bacon, butter, lard, &c., and the crew taken as prisoners.
They are now confined in Fortress Monroe.
Of the bacon, there were 1,000 pounds, valued at 25 cents; the butter, from 35 to 40 cents the lard, from 16 to 20 cents. Captain Adams, the owner, was in our city at the time, and went to Old Point immediately under a flag of truce, but did not succeed in gaining his property.

One thousand troops arrived at Newport News yesterday, exclusive of the one thousand that arrived at Old Point on Thursday.
It is now estimated that there are about twelve to thirteen thousand troops stationed at these points.

Two English vessels arrived in the Roads last evening.
I learn that Pendergast wished to search them, but this was promptly refused him.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
the Third Regiment of Yorktown.
div3.p:
Thinking you would like to hear from the Third Regiment, to-day I sit myself down to acquaint you with some of our proceedings.
In the first place, we are all well and in good spirits, with a few exceptions.
This morning in walking around camp, we noticed the messes in the various companies cooking breakfast; of course we tarried a little longer at the quarters of Capt. Walker's Life Guard, (they being the pride of the regiment,) whom we found busily engaged in preparing their savory meals.
Should the Third Regiment ever meet the enemy, the V. L. G. 's, will be found in the hottest of the fray.

The amusements of rumors have nearly ceased, and realities are hard upon us. I learn from very good authority that on yesterday 500 of the enemy approached within 12 miles of this place; the reason they came no farther is very presumable — somebody might get hurt.
Last night and this morning two large detachments of our men left here for the vicinity of the enemy, to give them a brush if possible.
May God speed them, and let them return successful.

Here we have around as in all directions the warlike ruins and remnants of the past.
Should the necessity of the times demand it, may their departed vitality return and battle in the cause of freedom, justice and right.

Our blockading friend, (the Federal war ship,) is still guarding with the fidelity of a Roman sentinel the entrance to our harbor.--Let him alone.
Every approachable entrance to this place is strongly guarded, many of the old redoubts being sites for new ones.
On the night before last, I visited the road and post which Washington came, and where he surprised the sentinels of Cornwallis.
The road leads through a deep and dismal swamp; it is now dug up to a depth of six feet or more, and full of water; so no fear from Yankee dom in that direction.
Should the minions of old Abe pay us a visit, the present host of the Yorktown House will give a better welcome than mine host of the past (Cornwallis) did to Washington.

In regard to the weather, the last two or three days it has been raining and wet here, which goes rather hard with those who are stationed on the various redoubts and pickets.
Circumstances compel me to close this letter very abruptly.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
Affairs in Charlotte county.
div3.p:
Charlotte has three companies in the field — the Charlotte Rifles, Captain T J. Spencer, stationed at Tudor Hall, three miles from Manassas Junction; the Charlotte Troop, Captain John J. Smith, at Ashland; the Keysville Rifles, at Hermitage Fair Grounds.
She has three more ready — aye, eager for the fray.

Mr. Wm. E. Green, a gentleman extensively known, is raising a company for the service of Virginia, and I understand he has already got 45 recruits, and, no doubt, would be anxious to get the required complement.
I would earnestly request all those citizens of Charlotte who desire to enlist to enroll their names on Mr. Green's list.
They cannot have a better commander.
Uniforms furnished free, &c.

Our able Commonwealth's Attorney, Wood Bouldin, has been elected to the Legislature, although he was not a candidate.
It may be well to remark in this place that Mr. Bouldin was our representative in the Convention, and represented us ably, too.

Our Home Guard numbers about 80 men. Its Captain, Col. Henry A. Carrington, of the Charlotte Militia, and a graduate of the Virginia Military Institute, has received an appointment as Lieutenant Colonel of the 2d Regiment of Virginia Volunteers, and proceeded a few days since to take command at Manassas Junction.

The crops are looking remarkably well.
Corn looks very well, and the wheat is turning yellow and will soon be ripe.
Very small crops of tobacco are planted in this section of the county.
We have been favored with several fine rains lately.
Our soldiers will not lack for provisions if they continue to grow as they now do.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch,
letter from Knoxville — patriotic Addresses from Hon. John Bell, ex Gov. Foote, &c.
div3.p:
On my route from Harper's Ferry to Lynchburg, and thence wherever I could snuff a favorable breeze, I met with a mutual friend from Richmond, and before separating at Gordonsville, I promised to send you a note of everything transpiring likely to be of interest to our brave soldiers in the camp, or our prudent and patriotic statesmen in the Cabinet.
Many things of importance, though in view of the magnitude of the contest of minor interest, have been deemed worthy a place in my note-book.
These will hereafter, when peace shall again smile upon our beloved Confederacy, and the Goths and Vandals be driven back to their Northern hive, form the ground-work of the episodes of the Revolution in Virginia.
At present, events pregnant with glorious results to our cause have occurred and are now transpiring in the political capital of Eastern Tennessee, which it is of the utmost importance to our cause and its success should be heralded by express messengers, if need be, to every camp and station on the frontiers of our State.

First, comes the glorious and patriotic speech of honest John Bell, of Tennessee, delivered this morning from the plaza of the Lamar House, to a Louisiana regiment, surrounded by thousands of citizens of Knoxville.
Oh, how my heart throbbed with emotions of exultation and hope when the venerable and eloquent Tennessee, slowly, almost tremulously, but emphatically declared, "You know, my friends, that I hoped for the preservation of the old Union, perhaps, as long as any other public man in the South.
I might and would have hoped still longer, but when I was startled, when the South was insulted and threatened, by the proclamation of Mr. Lincoln and its accompanying call for 75,000 men; when that call was followed up by another for 48,000 men, and the creation — for increase is not the term — of a navy to co-operate in the military movements in contemplation, I immediately flung behind my back all past party ties; I forgot that such political differences ever existed in Tennessee, and looking upon that flag which now so gracefully kisses the breeze before me, I made a solemn vow to Heaven, which I now renew, that the remaining days of my life shall be devoted to its service.
I am now getting old — perhaps too old to fight; but, my friends of East Tennessee, it may come to that, too; when it does, I am ready." The foregoing I have taken from my notes, and though it falls far short of the eloquence of delivery, it is in substance a correct report of that portion of his address.

Gov. H. S. Foote also addressed the assemblage of citizens and soldiers.
He spoke in his usual felicitous and stirring manner, but evidently showed the physical effects of an extensive canvass which he had made throughout Eastern Tennessee.

Later in the day, I attended a large and enthusiastic meeting at the Court-House.
When I entered, Col. Avery, of the Memphis district, was delivering one of those soul-stirring, practical speeches which characterized him in Washington as one of the wheel-horses of the Southern Democracy.
He excited the most unbounded enthusiasm, and for two hours commanded the unbroken attention of the vast assemblage.
When the Colonel concluded, Gov. Bell again took the stand merely to announce that on Thursday he would address his friends on the great question of the day; that his old Union friends from every point of the county would be present, and he desired especially to demonstrate to them, and to all who had so long and so faithfully clung to his political and personal fortunes, that devotion and fidelity to the South, in her present attitude of manly defence, is but a corollary of the principles which he has publicly proclaimed in Knoxville and elsewhere during the past thirty years.

In response to a general call, G. P. Foute, Esq., of Memphis, who accompanies Colonel Avery in the canvass of East Tennessee, took the stand, and, in a strain of fervent and patriotic eloquence, scattered the Union dogmas of the few recusants who still cling to the skirts of Parson Brownlow, and oppose Southern independence.
There will be few of them left by Saturday next, and Tennessee will on that day roll up 60,000 to 75,000 majority.
Should anything transpire of sufficient interest during my travels in Tennessee and Georgia, I will faithfully apprise you.

I ought to mention an incident that occurred at Bristol — a town on the borders of Virginia and Tennessee.
It will be read with interest at Richmond.
A gentleman passing through that place was invited to address a large number of Louisiana and Mississippi solders, then en route for Richmond.
In the course of his remarks, it was understood that he was bound for some point where he expected to raise a company or a battalion of Irish adopted citizens for Gen. Floyd's division, and that, whether he offered one or the other, he had official assurance of their acceptance.
This gentleman subsequently informed me that out of the fifteen or sixteen Irish citizens of the place, mostly engaged on the railroads, eleven called on him in the course of the day, offered their services, and pledged themselves to be ready to go with him to Abingdon or Richmond on his return from Georgia.
The adopted citizens, especially of Irish origin, are all right at heart, North as well as South.
The former will prove so in good time; the latter are multiplying proofs of it every day.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
from North Carolina.
div3.p:
All are ready for the war in these parts of the Old North State.
Almost every train on our railroad is filled with strong arms and brave hearted soldiers, pushing on to the defence of our cause, and the soil, and gallant men and women, of our good old mother and sister State, Virginia.
yesterday another company left old Guilford, and others will soon be ready to follow the three companies that have gone.
On last night's train many troops passed down, and in a day or two, we are told, Col. Fisher's regiment, from Rowane county, N. C., and some thousands more troops, are to pass here for Virginia.

Old Abe and his mercenaries will find thousands and thousands of our best men to meet them if they dare bring on an engagement, and this country has never witnessed such fighting as will be in this war; and from the quiet, resolute determination to conquer or die, I am more than sanguine that we will whip them back for their polluted feet should have no place on our sacred soil.
The whole South is in a blaze.
All of our young men have left town for the different fortifications on our coast.

Fort Caswell, just at the mouth of the Cape Fear, is in a perfect state of defence.
The last accounts stated that there were twenty-five 24-pounders, four 36-pounders, and ten large Columbiads mounted, and the boys hard at work mounting some which have been received from Charleston.
The fort is garrisoned by eight hundred men. Fort Johnson, situated at Smithville, is more of a rendezvous than a fort.
There are nearly six hundred men kept in readiness to sail over to Caswell at a moment's notice.

Regiments are passing through every day, destined for Virginia.
We always give them a hearty and enthusiastic reception.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
Appomattox Invincibles.
div3.p:
This company, commanded by Capt. James E. Robertson, the pride and flower of our county, has gone ! With confidence and pleasure do our people commend them to the attention and regard of the noble and honorable wherever they may go. They left this morning, in company with our worthy, patriotic and distinguished county man, Hon. Thomas S. Bocock, for your city.
Though at an early hour they had to take the cars, the love and admiration of the people for officers and soldiers brought together a large number to witness their departure.
Old Appomattox has still material enough left to make another volunteer company, and most nobly are her people responding to the demands of their country.
Dr.--Abbitt, zealous, active and fully alive to the crying exigencies of his country, is sparing no pains, counting no cost in the accomplishment of this end. He, too, like others who have gone from our county, will forego all the endearments of an interesting family and a comfortable home to serve his country.

div3.head: Those reports.
div3.p:
--During the entire day on Saturday last, the people of this county in all parts were considerably exercised over a rumbling noise that seemed to be passing through the elements, resembling the sound produced by the firing of cannon.
Many were the conjectures; some contending that a great battle was going on at this point, some at that and some at another point.
Some said it was distant thunder, some said that it came from blasting rock.
Now, that it has been ascertained that the contending forces by land and water were engaged in mortal combat throughout the day on Saturday, at Aquia Creek, and the distance by an air line supposed not to exceed a hundred miles, and from the actual experimental tests upon record of the travel of sound, we are inclined to the belief that the rumbling noise throughout this county, and the adjoining county of Amherst, was the effect of the cannonading between the contending forces at Aquia Creek. Levinston Star.

div3.head: War matters.
div3.p: From our Southern exchanges we make up the following summary:
troops from Texas.
The New Orleans Delta, of the 4th, says:

q.p:
The Marshall Guards and the Star Rifles, the former from Harrison county, Texas, and the latter from Cass county, in the same State, have arrived here in the steamer Texas, Captain Stinde, en route for Virginia.
The Marshall Guards are acknowledged to be the most efficient corps in Eastern Texas, composed of the flower of the manhood of Harrison county.
Lawyers, merchants, planters and mechanics are on the muster-roll.
Captain Bass, the commander of the company, is a distinguished graduate of the Virginia Military Institute.
He resigned the Presidency of the Marshall University to accept the captaincy of the Guards.
The company had had the benefit of his admirable military acquirements for the past year.
The Star Rifles accompany the Guards, and are commanded by Captain A G. Clopton, brother of Hon. David Clopton, ex-member of Congress from Alabama, and are every inch Texas.
The two companies will proceed to join their battalion, now in Virginia, as soon as mustered into service.

div3.p: Missouri.
The Jefferson City correspondent of the St. Louis Republican, writing on the 28th ult., says:

q.p:
You are probably aware that a message was recently received from Gen. Harney, directed to Gen. Price and Gov. Jackson, asking whether it would be a violation of the compact to march a regiment through the State to some point upon the border, to operate against any invasion from the frontier.
This request, I am informed, was politely declined.
Such a procedure, in the present inflammable state of the public mind, could not fall to precipitate a revolution and bring on war. Of course, we have every reason to believe that it was not entertained afterwards.
There is no doubt but that the Black Republicans are dissatisfied with the armistice.
Their object is revolution and war, and they will seek any pretext to obtain it. This is manifest from the course of the Democrat and the leaders.--Let them beware.

div3.p: Hints about Cairo.

The Mobile Tribune learns from a gentleman just from Corinth, Miss., that there are some twenty-one thousand men under arms at that place.
They were in high spirits and had every soldierly comfort, especially an abundance of vegetables.
Gen. Clark, who is in command, was satisfied that these troops could be thrown within twenty-four hours to any point on the border menaced by the hirelings at Cairo — many of whom, by the way, were deserting and joining our army.
This force at Corinth, within forty-eight hours, it was understood, could be increased to nearly forty thousand.
So that there is no probability that the scum at Cairo, even though it be brought up to eighty thousand--as is stated to be the purpose of A. L.--can do much harm to the border of Kentucky, Tennessee or Mississippi.
We hope that they may march into that region.
They and the hen-roosts are likely to be the only sufferers.
The men, we are certain, will never return to the soil which may vomit them forth for the wicked purpose of subjugating the Confederate States.
Their dead bodies will manure it, and nothing else good will come of the invasion.
the Texas Guerillas.

We learn from the Houston Telegraph that Captain T. S. Lubbock's Guerillas were to leave Houston on the 5th of June, to participate in the wars.
this company is made up of men who expect to pay their own way, and out of patriotism to do all the service in their power to the Confederate States.
It is understood that enterprises requiring peculiar daring, bold strokes of war, and so forth, will be given to this company.
Other companies like it are being fitted out, and they offer the best opportunity for brave men to do their country some service, and win honor for themselves, that can be found.
Grape and Canister.
Says the Memphis Bulletin:

q.p:
The Memphis and Charleston Railroad Company and Messrs. Quimby & Robinson's foundries, are daily turning out large quantities of grape and canister, as well as 32-pound shot.
It was grape that Bragg so terribly rained on the Mexicans at Buena Vista; and when our Cairo friends come down upon Memphis, they will find we can let them have a liberal supply of that peculiar "home manufacture."

div3.p: The Charleston News, of Thursday, says:

q.p:
Quite an excitement was created upon the street yesterday afternoon by the announcement that the privateer Savannah, formerly a pilot boat in our waters, had captured the brig Joseph, of Portland, Me., from Havana to Philadelphia, with a cargo of sugar, valued at $30,000, and had sent her into Georgetown, with a prize crew.
The privateer is commanded by Capt. Baker, and when last seen was being chased by a U. S. war vessel, but with very little likelihood of being captured.
When the Savannah left our harbor some days ago, a ball was fired across her bow from the blockading steamer, to bring her to, but the only answer given was a return shot at the steamer, as the little craft saucily continued on her way.

Prize Commissioner Gilchrist, will visit Georgetown to take official possession of the prize vessel, and as the cargo is classed among perishable articles, it will probably be sent to Charleston and sold, the proceeds remaining subject to the decision of the Court.

div3.p: Probable Addition to our Navy.
The Charleston Courier says:

q.p:
A gentleman just arrived in this city from New Orleans reports that the blockading steamer Brooklyn, at the mouth of the Mississippi, went ashore before he left, and that she careened to such a degree that her guns could not be made to bear on anything.
He further reports that the inhabitants were alive in preparation for relieving the Brooklyn and placing her under Confederate attentions.

div3.p: Movements of troops.
The Raleigh Standard says:

q.p:
We are glad to see that the whole South is in motion.
We learn that several thousand Southern troops have passed through Goldsboro' within a few days.
On Tuesday morning 200 Georgians passed through this city, and a large body of Southern troops are daily expected.

In the meantime, the North Carolina volunteers are rapidly congregating at the different rendezvous.
On Wednesday the city appeared to be alive with them.
Some four companies arrived on that day.

div3.p: Arkansas.

The Arkansas State Convention has passed a military bill, authorizing the Governor to call out 60,000 men if necessary.
It halves the State into two grand divisions, Eastern and Western, and appoints one Brigadier General for each.
Gen. Bradley was unanimously elected to the command of the Eastern, and Gen. Pierce, late of the United States Army, to the Western division.

div3.head: The Southern Bank Convention.
div3.p: The Bank Convention, which met in Atlanta, Ga., on the 3d inst., adjourned the same day to met in Richmond, Va., on the 24th of July. During the progress of the meeting, a verbal communication was furnished, to the effect that the Banks of Charleston had passed resolutions that each Bank had agreed to furnish $100,000 to the Government of the Confederate States, and take Treasury notes in payment.
The following report was unanimously adopted:

q.p: Resolved,That this Convention do recommend to all the Banks in the Southern Confederacy to receive in payment of all dues to them the Treasury notes of the Government, to be issued under the act of Congress of May 16th, 1860, and also to receive the same on deposit and pay them out again to customers.

Resolved.That until the said Treasury notes can be prepared and issued, it be recommended to all the Banks to agree to advance to the Government in current notes such sums severally as may be agreed upon between them and the Secretary of the Treasury.
The said advance to be made on the deposit with the Banks of Treasury notes of a large denomination, or 8 per cent. stock or bonds.

Resolved,That all the Banks in the Southern Confederacy are earnestly urged to take immediate action on the foregoing resolutions, as a measure of the greatest importance to the Government and the people, and communicate the same without delay to the Secretary of the Treasury at Richmond.
Resolved,That it be recommended to all the railroad companies in the Southern Confederacy to receive the Treasury notes in payment of fares and freight.

Resolved,That the Legislature of the several States be recommended to make it lawful for the tax collectors and other officers to receive the Treasury notes in payment for taxes and all other public dues.

Resolved,That all the States, cities and corporations having coupons payable in the city of New York, or elsewhere in the enemys country, be requested during the continuance of the war to appoint some place of payment in the Confederate States, and to give their creditors notice of the same.
Resolved, That the Committee recommend that when this Convention adjourns it adjourn to meet again on the 24th day of July next at Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Additional foreign News.
div3.p: The steamship Borussia, which arrived at New York on the 4th inst., brings the following additional news:
the London Times on President Davis' Message.
The London Times, of the 22d ult., publishes President Davis' Message to the Southern Congress entire, and closes an editorial comment upon it in the following language:

q.p:
"Mr. Davis, while making a studious display of moderation, and endeavoring to conciliate the good will of European nations, is perfectly aware that his theories depend for acceptance on the rifles of his fellow citizens.
The tribunal which decides questions of international law is usually a stern one.
If the North prevails, it will prove that the Union was a nationality; if the South makes good its independence, it will prove that the Union was a partnership during pleasure.

"This is what has to be decided, and we must wait the event.
For the present, there is no indication of a peaceful issue.
The secession of the border States seems to have been hastened rather than delayed by the formidable preparations at the North.
Tennessee and Arkansas are said to have gone over.
The former is a great addition to the resources of the Southerners; the latter is of comparatively little weight.
Virginia and North Carolina are preparing for the war which must take place on their borders, while Kentucky still remains neutral, though the Governor is said to be in correspondence with the Secessionists.

"On the other hand, the enthusiasm of the North is as great as ever, and the first movements in the war may be shortly looked for, though they will, it is said, be limited to the occupation of Harper's Ferry, and one or two other places on the Virginia frontier.
A more important matter is, however, mentioned.
We have already anticipated that the campaign could not begin in earnest for same months, and that the volunteers who marched to Washington must be replaced by regular troops.
This, it is now declared, will be the case.
Though there may be desultory fighting in the interval, yet the real invasion of the Confederate States is not to take place fill the fall of the year, when it is to be executed by a standing army of 100,000."

div3.p: Miscellaneous News.
The Moniteur of Sunday, May 19, says:

q.p: A circular, addressed by Count Persigny, the Minister of the Interior, to the Prefects, calling their attention to the prosecution of the printer and publisher of a paper entitled "A Letter on the History of France," and inviting them to watch with care for any attempt at publication, which may be made in the name of persons who have been either banished or exiled.

div3.p: M. de Persigny says that, under whatever form books, journals and pamphlets may make their appearance, the Prefects are in such cases to seize them by administrative authority, and make a report on the subject to the Ministry.
The Minister reminds the Prefects that, by judicial seizure, the writer of a pamphlet is protected against all reply and recrimination, and says:

q.p: "It is thus that one representing the policy of 1840 was able with impurity to address this strange question to the victor of Solferino: "[What have you done with France]"

div3.p: The Paris correspondent of the Times says:

q.p:
Commercial men for the present no longer occupy themselves with foreign politics.
They are now directing their attention to the financial difficulties apprehended from the vast demands which are about to be made on the money market.
On Monday the Bank of France opened a subscription for the railroad companies, who want to raise a sum of 230,000,000f.

The next demand on the public will be for 104,000,000 francs as a government loan for thirty years. The next demand is a loan for 500,000,000 francs for the new Kingdom of Italy.
Some doubts are entertained as to whether the Kingdom of Italy will be recognized so long as the French troops remain at Rome.

A slight decline took place in the Paris flour market last week.
Wheat was firm.

After June 1st consols will be quoted ex-dividend, so that their present price is really only a fraction above 90.
The bar silver brought by the West India steamer was sold at 60½ per ounce, showing an advance of 3/8d.
The Copenhagen had arrived from Australia with £705,000.
The demand for money at the Bank of England on Monday was quiet.
About £3,000 was taken to the Bank. £40,000 had arrived from Constantinople.

div3.p: Commercial.

Money Market.--London, Thursday evening, May 21.--There is not the slightest symptom of revival, and consols are still at the price at which they have stood, almost exclusively, for a month past, viz: 91 ½ a ¾ for money, and 91 ½ a Ȃ for account.
Loans on Government securities continue to be offered at 4 a 4 ½ per cent.

The demand in the discount market has been moderate, and 6 per cent. is the usual rate.
At the Bank applications were limited.
The last price from Paris on Tuesday evening was 69f. 50, showing an advance of ½.--Foreign exchanges are firm.
American railway securities were dull, and Illinois Central shares declined $1.

Liverpool Cotton Market,May 20th and 21st. --There has been an extensive demand for cotton, and the sales for the two days exceed 25,000 bales, 13,000 on speculation and for export.
Prices against the buyer.
London Corn Market, Monday, May 21.--The market showed a tendency to flatness.

Liverpool Corn Market,May 21.--Both wheat and flour met with a very limited trade, at the rates of last week.
Oats, barley, beans and peas, unchanged.
Indian corn dull.
Mixed American, 33s. 9d, a34s.; yellow, 34s. 6d, a34s. 9d.; white 34s. 6d. a35s. 6d.

div3.head: Telegraphic items.
div3.p: We find the following in the Memphis papers:

St. Louis, June 5.--Gen. Price has issued his proclamation to the Brigadier Generals commanding the Militia Districts of Missouri.
That his efforts in every station have been to prevent the transfer of the battle-field from the Atlantic States to Missouri.
The right of Missourians to bear arms is undoubted, and to secure this right peacefully he and Harney compromises on terms alike honorable to Missouri and the United States.

The Administration has removed Harney, but doubtless his successor will adhere to it, in letter and spirit.
Its violation would be a gross insult to the veterans of Missouri, and would be resisted to the last extremity.
The people of Missouri cannot be forced into submission.
It attempted, let no apprehension be entertained as to the result.
Six Regiments are now en route for Cairo.
Washington,June 5.--The forward movements were made last night, the Federals being afraid to stir in consequence of several thousand Southerners appearing at Centreville, 16 miles below.
Alexandria,June 5.--The troops here are only supplied with eight days rations.
A Federal scouting party was captured near Hampton, Va.
Louisville,June 5.--Immense quantities of provisions have been and are now being shipped over the Louisville and Nashville Railroad to the Secession States.

The present Collector, being a Secessionist, refused to obey orders stopping shipments South.
A new Collector has been appointed, and will enter upon his duties in a few days.

To support him it was intended to send the so-called Kentucky Brigade to Louisville, but the War Department has been advised that Kentuckians would bear more patiently the presence of an army of the Federal troops than the bogus Kentucky Brigade, and that the Unionists especially deprecated their coming.
They will probably be ordered to Washington, and the Home Guard like that at St. Louis will be ordered to Louisville.

Louisville,June 5.--The Border State Convention has issued an address to the people of Kentucky, signed by all except ex-Gov. Morehead, who says in a note: I approve of the refusal to furnish troops, and favor the policy of neutrality without committing myself to all that is said on other matters.
An address to the people of the United States was signed by all, (including John Caldwell, of Tennessee,) except Morehead.
St. Louis, June 5.--Mayor Taylor has resigned.
Eighty men from Hannibal, forming part of a battalion of Home Gurd, were sworn into the U. S. service, armed, and returned with arms for their comrades, who will be sworn in also.

Leavenworth,June 5.--Twelve volunteers from Lincoln, armed with Minnie rifles and revolvers, crossed the river 12 miles above here, to demand the Secession flag in the name of the United States.
The flag was hauled down by them, but on their return the Secessionists attacked them, wounding three of the volunteers, one severely.
Washington,June 5.--Gen. Scott disapproves of the landing of forces at Aquia Creek.

All dispatches announcing that hostilities will soon occur at Aquia Creek and Manassas Junction, are declared to be incorrect.
Several members of the Maryland Legislature have visited recently Richmond, doubtless to confer with the Confederate leaders.

Baltimore,June 5.--The barkGen.
Green, owned in Charleston, has been captured.
The Merrill & Thomas guns factory has been seized.

Marshal Kane, the Baltimore correspondent of the New York Tribune says, is as bed at heart as Merriman; he boasts that the Government is afraid to arrest him. His friends threaten to rise if he is touched.

div3.head: Adventures of an Alabama Company
div3.p: --The Landerdale Rifles Attacked by an armed Mob in East Tennessee--No one Hurt — Their Safe Arrival at Richmond.
On Saturday last we were called upon by an officer of the Lauderdale (Ala) Rifles, who gave us the following interesting narrative of the adventures of the company while on the way to Virginia:

div4.p:
The Landerdale Rifles left North Alabama last Monday with the hope and desire of reaching Richmond in three days, but owing to delays caused by the trains running off the track, we were not allowed to reach your beautiful city until last night about 12 o'clock. Allow me to thank the kind people of Alabama, Virginia, and some of Tennessee, for their many kindnesses showed us, and especially the ladies of Dublin, Va., who gave us a very nice dinner.
My object in addressing this short note to you, is two-fold; first, to thank the good people of Virginia and Alabama; 2d, and to make a true statement of the affray that took place about one mile this side of Strawberry Plains.
We were detained at Strawberry Plains about two hours, and while there we saw the old flag of the once glorious Union; and the sight of that banner — now the emblem of tyranny and oppression — filled our men with rage, and immediately a determination arose to take it down; but the interference of our officers stopped them.
In the meanwhile, there was a spy sent from the Union men, who had just passed us with some five or six hundred strong, with some five or six flags, all indicating oppression, and by that means they found out that we were unarmed; and as we passed along the road where they had collected to something like two thousand strong to hear Brownlow, Maynard and others make their last desperate effort to carry Tennessee with the North, they began to rock us and level their guns on us. Our men all saw the guns bearing directly upon us, but did nothing until they began to throw rocks at us, and then, and not until then, one of our men threw a rock at them, and immediately they began a heavy fire on us, which our men answered by firing some fifteen or twenty times at them with repeaters.
The cars did not halt; so we do not know whether we hurt any of them or not. None of our men were hurt.
Some balls they shot at us struck our cars.
Some hit above our heads, and some hit the side.
We were in open cars.
We did not have our flag up. It was kept down at the request of our friends at Strawberry Plains.
div4.closer: W. C.Reeder. 1st Lieut. Lauderdale Rifle Co., Ala.

div3.head:
Affairs at Pensacola.
[from the N. O. Delta, 4th inst.
div3.p:
From gentlemen who have just arrived from Pensacola, we learn that the twenty-six hundred troops detached from Gen. Bragg's army for the seat of war in Virginia got off in fine style and great spirits.
They include our two splendid battalions, the volunteers from Louisiana, who have elected as their field officers Capt. Dreux, of the Cadets, as Lieutenant Colonel, and Capt. Rightor, of the Grivol Guards, as Major, and the Zouaves under Lieut. Col. Coppens.
These two battalions make up an effective force of twelve hundred men. A Georgia and Alabama regiment complete the detachment.

There will be no more efficient body of troops in the field than this force.
They have been in service nearly two months and have now all the qualities of regular troops.--Dreux's volunteers are picked men, the slite of our State, and the Zouaves are the only real Zouaves in the country.
The mongrel organizations of city rowdies sent from the North under the title of Zouaves are burlesques upon that splendid corps.
Our Zouaves are Zouaves in reality, and cannot be distinguished from the best in the French service.
Among them are about 200 old French soldiers.
Several of the commissioned and all of the non-commissioned officers have been officers in the French service, and their uniform is precisely that of the French corps; they are commanded in French, and their drill is strictly that of the French Light Infantry.
We pity the Northern force which comes in contact with our Zouaves.
Those who stand before them must be prepared for close work.
The Zouaves prefer steel to lead.

This reduction of Bragg's command leave him an ample force to conduct all the operations in the reduction of Fort Pickens.
The enemy have landed a reinforcement on Santa Rosa of several hundred men, and a large supply of provisions, including live cattle.--Their purpose is evidently to establish an entrenched camp on the island, and to stand a long siege.
We pity the poor mercenaries.
We regret that they are not New England or New York volunteers, instead of unfortunate foreigners, who have been compelled to enlist in order to keep them from starvation and want.
Their destruction, either by sickness or by Bragg's batteries, is inevitable.

Meantime, our sagacious and energetic General is strengthening and augmenting his batteries and making other arrangements which will render the result a complete and glorious one.
The only fear is that Old Brown may be able to steal off with his command in the transports which are kept continually anchored off the island.
This would be very unfortunate.
We have a double claim to Old Brown.
In addition to his perils from Bragg's batteries and bayonets, he owes a certain responsibility to the laws of Florida for negro stealing, which will probably consign him to the Penitentiary for life.

Great alarm prevails in Fort Pickens.--Brown and his officers have no confidence in their men. He never trusts any of them out of sight of the forts.
If it were not for the intervening bay, half of them would desert.
The attempt to float out the dry-dock, owing to the want of steamers, did not prove a success, and she was sunk in the bay.

It is entirely untrue and absurd to pretend that this was done in consequence of threats from Brown to fire upon the party attempting to sink her in the channel; we never saw the necessity or advantage of sinking her as an obstruction in the channel.
Bragg has no fear of the fleet attempting to enter the Bay.
Indeed, we ought to-desire such an attempt to be made.
The destination or capture of the ships making such an attempt is a sure thing.
They ought to be invited and coaxed in. Brown, however, was much exercised about this dock.
He magnified the great clumsy thing into a floating battery, and sent two messages to Bragg about it. The first was a long letter, containing a ponderous argument on the political issues of the present conflict, concluding with a fearful threat of what he intended to do in case the dock should be brought near the fort.
After reading this letter, Bragg informed Capt. Hartsuff--Brown's Adjutant General--that it required no reply, and he had none to make to it.

Another communication came soon, after from Brown, in which he reiterated his threat, and expressed the hope that he would be saved the disagreeable necessity of commencing the conflict.
In this letter Brown referred to the dock as a floating battery.
Bragg deigned a reply to this communication, in order, as he stated, to relieve the fears of an old companion-in-arms, apprising him that the dock in question was not a Trojan horse or a floating battery, and contained only bricks and stone, and that he (Brown) might repose in peace and security, so far as the floating monster was concerned.
Affairs have been more quiet at Pickens since old Brown received these assurances.

div3.head: Good example.
div3.p: --We take pleasure in publishing the following, sent us by a correspondent:

It was my pleasure a few evenings ago to hear the Rev. Samuel Register, a native of Maryland, and a prominent minister of the Methodist Church, make the most able and eloquent appeal to a portion of the citizens of Rockbridge county to rally to their country's call, which I have heard by any man yet.--He discussed in a masterly manner the justness of our cause, and appealed to all, old and young, male and female, to sustain with all their ability, either by taking their muskets, applying their needles, and giving their prayers in behalf of their soil which had been pointed by an invading foe; that he entertained no fears of the final result, for, as he confidently felt, the God of Battles was with us, and our President (whom he knew) was a God fearing man. It seems to me that if the people generally could hear him, they would be at once inspired with confidence, and ready to sacrifice friends and comfort, for the accomplishment of so just and holy a cause. H.

div3.head: Resignations accepted.
div3.p: --The following resignations of U. S. army officers were accepted on June 1st: Major Wm. H. Bell, Ordnance; Captain Bounycastle, Assistant Quartermaster; Captains Field, of the 2d Cavalry; Schroeder, of the 3d Infantry, and Steele, of the 2d Dragoons; Lieuts. Cooke, of the 8th; Infantry; Corley, of the 6th; Adelin, of the 7th; Wright, of the Ordnance, and Alexander, of the Engineers.

div3.head: Crevasse.
div3.p:
--We have been favored with the following extract from a private letter, dated Natchez, June 1. "The river broke through the loves on the Louisiana side last night, the encroaching flood rushing through into Lake Concordia.
It is playing sad havoc among the plantations.
The breach in the loves is 250 feet wide and from six to ten feet deep.
N. O. Picayune, 4th.

div3.head: Shizurn of Kanawha Salt.
div3.p:
--The Nashville papers state that two flat-boats, laden with 1,892 barrels of Kanawha salt, intended for that city, had been seized at Evansville, Ind., and the crew taken prisoners.
The salt and the boats that contained it were confiscated.

div3.head: Tents for the Volunteers.
div3.p:
--It has been announced, through the correspondence of our gallant volunteers, that many of them are without tents and exposed to the weather, with no protection but the boughs of trees.
Most of our volunteers have been accustomed to the enjoyment of every comfort at their homes, and will soon be rendered unfit for service if subjected to such exposure during the present inclement season.
We are informed that the cost of a tent sufficient for the accommodation of ten men is just twelve dollars, or a little more than an average of one dollar for each man. An enterprising gentleman of this city is prepared to furnish the material and make up five hundred tents a week.
It thus appears that funds sufficient for 5,000 men could be furnished by a single house in this city in one week, and yet the two Regiments of volunteers from this city--one in the field at Yorktown, and the other at Manassas Junction, consisting of less than 2,000 men — have been for several weeks past without any other covering than is enjoyed by the beasts of the field.
Will not our wealthy and patriotic citizens come forward and contribute for the equipment of our own Regiments?
If our worthy Mayor would call a meeting of the citizens, the requisite funds could be raised in a single day, and in less than a week every soldier in our Regiments would be supplied with comfortable tents.

div3.head: A trusty sword wanted.
div3.p:
--Robert L. Francisco, grandson of the celebrated Peter Francisco, a private in Capt. C. A. Ronald's company of Highland Rangers, from Montgomery county, Va., now on duty at Harper's Ferry, desires to obtain the sword, now in the Armory in Richmond, which was made to the order of his celebrated revolutionary ancestor, to be used in the war of 1812. It is five feet in length and heavy in proportion, and it will take a man of considerable longitude to draw it from its seaboard.
Robert L. Francisco bears more resemblance to his Samson-like ancestor in size and strength than any of his ancestry.
We trust the Governor may send him the sword, with a pledge to return it, if he survives the "shock of battle;" and that he may do that, and emulate the example of Peter Francisco, of revolutionary fame, in making at least nine Hessiaus bite the dust, is the prayer of all good people.

div3.head: A lady's wit and its results.
div3.p:
--A Tennessee lady, who has been passing some time at Ashland, was (while promenading the beautiful grounds which adorn that place) accosted by a gentleman, who seemed to be arranging a bouquet, with the inquiry if there were any laurels, either in the grounds or the woods near by. Noticing that he was in citizen's dress, she replied promptly, and with much meaning in her dark eye: "No, sir; but I understand that the Virginians have recently gathered a great many at Aquia Creek, Sewell's Point and Fairfax Court-House.
I doubt not there are still more left at those places, and many other parts of Virginia." The hint was not lost.
A few days after, the gentleman joined a gallant corps, and is now at Manassas, no doubt determined to reap a harvest of laurels with his own good blade.

div3.head: A Sensible dog.
div3.p:
--The Louisiana Cadets, which arrived on Friday evening from Pensacola, brought in their ranks a superb Newfoundland dog, who, disgusted with his fare and company, deserted from Fort Pickens, and swam into our camp.
It is needless to say that the sagacious animal at once found himself among friends, and if the other brutes with whom he had been associating possessed half the decent instincts of this quadruped, they, too, would leave for some safer place than the beleaguered fortress.
There is more humanity in one wag of that dog's caudal appendage than can be scraped together in the entire Abolition army with a fine-tooth comb.

div3.head: Mayor's Court, Saturday.
div3.p: --Five men, arrested for drunkenness, fighting, going to rest in the public streets, &c., were arraigned, and, after receiving an admonition, were discharged.--Degrassy Drumwright, a hard old case, recently ordered out of the city as a notorious character, having been arrested hero on information furnished by telegraph, was committed for a further hearing.--Delphia Jackson, Margaret Wilson and Della Wilson, free negroes, who had been caught by the police exchanging salutations in the streets of bad words and rocks, were ordered to be whipped.

A splendid floral present was sent to Mrs. Jefferson Davis, at the Spotswood House, on Saturday, by Mr. E. G. Eggeling, the well known florist.
We are not sufficient adepts in the language of flowers to describe the bouquet, which was built on frame wicker-work about two feet high.
There was a bed of roses and rare exotics covering a space of twenty-four inches in diameter most beautifully arranged, surrounding which was a mossy embankment of "linked sweetness," the whole presenting a tout ensemble of fragrant beauty rarely met with.

Private Thompson Tyler, of the Richmond Light Infantry Blues, has received the appointment of Orderly to Brigadier General Henry A. Wise.
Several companies of soldiers, some of them well known here, have expressed a desire to be attached to the brigade now being formed by Ex-Governor Wise.--In this connection we may remark that Capt. O. J. Wise, of the Richmond Light Infantry Blues, returned to this city from Aquia Creek on Saturday, after five or six weeks absence in camp and on the battle-field, fighting the Northern heathen.

div3.head: Nurses for the Army.
div3.p:
--A number of efficient nurses are required by the demands of the service to take proper care of the sick and invalid soldiers who are now contending for liberty against a worse than savage foe.--Knowing the characteristic patriotism of our ladies, we believe on learning the above feet that the question will be with them not who shall go, but who shall stay behind.
Ladies who may feel interested in the subject can obtain all necessary information by calling on Mrs. A. F. Hopkins, at the American Hotel.

div3.head: Louisiana Volunteers.
div3.p:
--The battalion of Louisiana volunteers that arrived in our city on Friday night are commanded by the following officers: Col., C. Dreux; Adjutant, Thos. A. Smith.
Companies — Orleans Cadets, 99 men, Lieut. Burd commanding; Louisiana Guard, 109 men, Capt. S. Mfcu.
Todd; Crescent Rifles, (Company A.) 108 men, Capt. S. W. Fisk; Grivot Guards, 116 men, Capt. N. H. Righter; Shreveport Greys, 128 men, Capt. J. H. Beard.

The Jefferson Guard, of this city, have organized permanently, by the selection of Thos. J. Moncure (a V. M. I. graduate) as Captain; first Lieutenant, George Bell; second Lieutenant L. H. Frayser; Sergeants, James Moore, first; Edward C. Folkes, second; A. B. Wells, third; William H. Williams, fourth.
The company is in a flourishing condition, and has a large membership.

James R. Lawrence, a white man, was arrested on Saturday and carried before the Mayor as a person of evil fame, and for having no visible means of support.
He was locked up till his case could be inquired into.
There are a large number of "gentlemen of elegant leisure" here now who have no visible means of support, save what their shrewdness enables them to filch from others.

div3.head: Business is Reviving.
div3.p:
--The presence of those in authority has inspired renewed confidence in the perpetuity of our glorious Confederacy, which the presence of "noble men, in armor bright," is not at all calculated to weaken.
We never, in the most peaceful times, saw the streets more alive than they were on Saturday with moving humanity of all kinds.

All the former inmates of the Mechanics' Institute are now moving out, the Building having been hired to the Confederate States Government, who will use it for the War Department and Patent Office in future.
We presume, of course, that no fair can be held in the building next fall, as usual.

div3.head: Increasing circulation.
div3.p:
The daily circulation of the Dispatch now exceeds twenty thousand.
This is a wonderful increase, and one altogether without precedent in the South.

div3.head: Notice to our Subscribers.
div3.p:
Subscribers to the Dispatch will observe the Cross Mark on their papers when their subscriptions are about to expire.
Those who wish to renew will forward the amount, or the papers will be stopped at the close of the term for which they have paid.

div3.head: Send us the News.
div3.p:
Our friends at the various camps and places of rendezvous and elsewhere, will confer a favor by sending to us any interesting intelligence, at the earliest practicable moment for publication.
We desire to keep our readers informed in regard to everything that transpires, and will pay an adequate compensation for important news.

Among our contemporaries of the press who have lately visited our city, it has given us pleasure to meet with Mr. Moses, of the Charleston Mercury.
Our editorial friends from abroad will always find our "latch string out," and we shall be most happy to meet them.

Among the strangers now in our city, we have been most happy to meet Johnson J. Hooper, Esq., of Montgomery, the brilliant orator and wit. Mr. Hooper is the Secretary of the Southern Congress, and is equally admired for his genius and humor, and for the sterling qualities of the high-toned gentleman.
"Simon Suggs," if Mr. Hooper had never produced anything else, would alone immortalize him.

Col. T. G. Bacon, the gallant and accomplished Colonel of the Seventh Regiment of South Carolina Volunteers, has long been known among the friends of the turf as one of the most liberal patrons of the genuine Southern and British sport.
The Colonel is an old competitor of our Virginia Napoleon, Mr. Doswell; but at present he comes upon a different mission.
His blooded horses have always made good time; but we question whether any of them can run for a short distance as fast as some of the Lincoln quarter nags, when they come in sight of the Carolina riders.

div3.head: The Northwest.
div3.p:
The hive of traitors in Northwestern Virginia have brought disgrace upon the name of a State which has ever treated them with a liberality and indulgence to which they had no claims, and with whose character and interests they never had the slightest sympathy.
They have demonstrated that they are not Virginians, and when their career is ended we hope to see their section handed over to any State which can prove itself vile and degraded enough to deserve such an appendage.
Before that is done, however, they ought to be thoroughly conquered, and their leaders punished for treason.
That they are guilty of treason, they will not themselves deny.
Whatever question may be raised on other points, there is none as to the supreme allegiance of a citizen to his State.
The Northwest must be purified; the disgusting Buckeyes, who have dared to defile the soil of Virginia with their buzzard carcases, must be driven back to their unclean holes; the Virginia Benedict Arnolds must be dealt with as they deserve; and then, let the Pan-Handle and its accessories be presented, as you would give a leather medal as a premium for ugliness, to any State that can show itself, by bearing off the palm from all others in trucking, cowardice and depravity, worthy of such a reward of villainy.

div3.head: Iron-Plated vessels.
div3.p:
The success of the iron-plated gunboats of Napoleon in the attack upon the fortifications at Kinburn, near the close of the Russian war, should attract the attention of our authorities to the value of such vessels in reducing the fortifications at Old Point.
The efficiency of the floating iron battery at Charleston in the reduction of Fort Sumter is another suggestive fact, as is also the additional fact that some of our own defences, which are shielded with iron, as all ought to be, have resisted, with perfect impunity, the heaviest shot and shell of attacking squadrons.
The large iron frigates lately built in England and France could compete with any fortifications.
Why could not the Merrimack and other U. S. vessels, lately recovered at the Norfolk Navy-Yard, be put in a coat of iron armor?
At any rate, considering the value of iron-shielded vessels in cutting through ice of tremendous thickness, and in assailing fortifications, and of the facilities which we possess for constructing such fabrics, it does seem a matter deserving immediate examination whether we cannot build here in Richmond an iron structure, propelled by steam, which can make its mark upon Old Point.

div3.head:
Vessels at our wharves — can they not be
adapted to war purposes?
div3.p:
In a late visit to the docks, we observed quite a number of fine schooners and brigs now lying idle, which it would seem might be made use of in the work of defence.
Commodore Perry gained the battle of Lake Erie with a fleet which we are inclined to think did not have one vessel in it as staunch and capable of being adapted to war purposes as some of those now at our wharves.
Whether any of these vessels could be iron-plated we do not pretend to know.
However that may be, it will be remembered that before the battle of New. Orleans, the American flotilla rendered invaluable service, and it would seem that in the defence of our peninsula, at least that portion of it watered by the James, these vessels could be made to render most valuable service.
With a few pivot guns they could be stationed at such places as would give material aid to our land batteries, and attack any vessels which might assail those positions.

div3.head: The Southern Literary messenger.
div3.p:
We are glad to see that notwithstanding the war, the Messenger (for June) shows its smiling face with its usual punctuality.
The editor, Dr. Bagby, (whose Washington letters to the Dispatch last winter were read with such interest,) has gone to the field, as a private in Capt. Latham's Lynchburg company.
Many friends have come forward to assist in the editorial department during the absence of the editor, and we now want to see that Southern public come forward and sustain such a magazine as it deserves.
The absence of the editor in such a cause ought to be the reason for the presence of the public in full force in support of his magazine.

div3.head: Rejection of Burlingame by the Austrian Cabinet.
div3.p:
--It is stated that information has reached Washington that the Austrian Cabinet have declined to receive the Lincoln Ministers, Burlingame.
His rejection, (his friends say,) is not to be interpreted into any unfriendliness on the part of the Austrian Court, but is personal to Mr. B., from his agency in procuring the passage of the bill raising the Sardinian legation to a full mission.

div3.head: Jonathan out of favor at Court.
div3.p:
The inflammation of Yankee Doodle at the unexpected turn of affairs in England is delightful to behold.
If there is anything especially reverenced by that order of Doodle which new has control of the neighboring Republic, it is the English press and aristocracy.
New England, especially, has been more electrified by a friendly pat on the head from John Bull than ever spaniel was by the caress of a master.
Considering that the country was originally settled by the bitterest enemies and rebels with whom Great Britain ever had to contend — that it was mostly Puritan, with but a slight admixture of the Cavalier stock — it is perfectly miraculous to see the adulation and sycophancy of everything English which has of late been universal among the "Sons of the Pilgrims." Mrs. Harriet Beecher Stowe must be nearly dead by this time from a softening of the brain, produced by the skillful manipulations of the English aristocracy; and Sumner has attained the height of human happiness by being permitted to thrust his legs under the mahogany of several Lords.
New England travellers have made Old England their special study and delight, and, by direct of the foulest misrepresentations of Southern character, and a systematic puffery of their own various good qualities, supposed they had put the South completely out of the possibility of being regarded in civilized circles as anything but a horde of vulgar Barbarians.
Finally, Wm. H. Seward, having left the John Brown train in good condition for an explosion during his absence, went to England to clinch mattters, was invited to Royal and ducal tables, and came back to America with the full conviction that he had the whole world — at least the American part of it — in a sling; and that, if the South rebelled against its Northern master, he would reduce it to quiet in "sixty days," and England would shout and hurrah and cheer him on to our destruction.

Jonathan has been reckoning, as we long ago warned him, without his host.
We have labored for years in vain to impress upon that self-confident individual that, though he is very smart, he is, as the witty Mr. Littimer would observe, "very young." Great Britain is a country so old in years and mature in experience that the whole of Jonathan's lifetime is with her but a single day; and yet this ignorant Doodle supposed that this ancient and sagacious empire did not see through his little tricks and comprehend his artful dodges and permit him to suppose that he was using her for his purposes, whilst in reality he was but clay in the hands of the potter!
A nation has to live a great many years before it becomes as wise in council and consummate in diplomacy as the Government of England, the freest, the most sagacious, and the most powerful Government on the face of the globe.

We are not at all astonished at the wrath manifested by the Northern press at the course of England, especially the debate in the House of Lords, in which all the speakers recognize the South as equally a belligerent with the North, and in which the threat of hanging privateers is denounced as shocking to civilization.
If they will only keep cool, they will learn a good deal from that debate.
They must admire the dignity and courtesy which always distinguish gentlemen in discussion, especially in the Parliament of England, and they may learn that when they give way to their tempers, and deal in such abuse and vituperation as is common to their rostrum and press, they are only demonstrating that they do not understand the spirit and are incapable of the manners of gentlemen.
This is a small matter, we know, but it may improve their style at the next session of Congress.--Moreover, they must see from the apprehensions expressed by various speakers in that debate, there is very considerable danger that large numbers of English privateers will be after their commerce with a sharp stick, and that the English Government will not expect them to be treated as pirates.
More important than all, all the speakers concur in representing the South as a belligerent power, and the whole weight of the debate clearly shows that England will sooner or later throw her ponderous shield upon the side of the Confederate States.
Now, it is perfectly useless for Jonathan to be hectoring John Bull, as he is doing at this moment, and expecting that Commodore Stringham can sink the whole British Navy and Gen. Dan. Sickles overrun Canada.
We venture to say that England will not be intimidated by these menaces.
It is more probable that, in the event of a war with England, the Northern States will be crushed to a jelly between the upper and nether millstones of Canada and the South, that the whole U. S. Navy will be sunk and captured, and every Northern city on the Atlantic seaboard bombarded and burnt up, than that the North could make an impression equal to the puncture of a pin upon any vital point of the British Empire.
Instead of making herself ridiculous by puerile threats and grimaces, she would better heed the counsels of the wise and good men in her midst; of the Vallandinghams and the Pierces, and desist from this most vindictive, unnatural and diabolical war; for it is as certain as the rising of to-morrow's sun, if the South can show that she can maintain her position, and cannot be conquered by the North, England and France will see that our ports are open, will recognize our independence, and will compel the North to keep the peace.

div3.head: What they are coming to.
div3.p:
The Washington Government started out in this war with a debt of a hundred millions.--Its expenses per diem of all sorts cannot be far less than a million of dollars.
By the meeting of Congress there will be a hundred millions of deficiencies to meet, and a prospective expenditure of two or three hundred millions to authorize and to provide for. If a public debt be a public blessing, the North is soon to be immersed in an ocean of complete beatitude.
The end of the first year of the war will find a debt of five hundred millions of dollars, and the prospect of an indefinite increase.
The only limit to the debt will be in the capacity of the Northern market to take up the loans.
That capacity is not very great, for your Wall street capitalists are, in general, but mere agents for foreign lenders of money.
In all New York there are not a hundred million of dollars of genuine New York capital for loan.
All the rest of the money they have had at command has come from abroad, and belonged to foreigners.

Debentures of the Washington Government cannot command sale for a very long time.
They are but the obligations of a sectional Northern Government.
The South has withdrawn and will never consent to pay any part of the debt now growing up. It will be a debt of the North alone.
Probably Kentucky and Maryland will have the felicity of sharing in its burden to the extent of forty or fifty millions cash; but except such part as the prudent States of the border shall share, it will be a debt of the North.
As such it cannot command favor among foreign capitalists; for these people know very well that all the financial power and commercial wealth of the North were derived from its dealings with the South.
There is not enough capital in the North to support a large increase of the public debt, and the Government before a great while will

be bankrupt.
The Treasury is already in a state of collapse.

The first expedient they will resort to, after exhausting the resources of public loans, will be a National Bank.
The Herald is already calling out lustily for a National Bank, with a hundred millions of capital.
They will authorize one, of several hundred millions, and the Government will employ all the agency and resources of that institution to sustain its credit and to supply itself with money.
The Washington Government itself will subscribe to its capital.
Each Northern State will subscribe liberally.
Beef and other contractors of the army will subscribe some of their hundreds of thousands of profits; and other fortunate speculators, looking to further little favors and to further good luck, will take many shares.--It will be a stupendous affair, a colossal machine, a magnificent bubble; and thus, with a high protective tariff, a huge National Bank, a mammoth public debt, and a vast standing army, all in full blast, the Northern ideal of a great and strong Government will be completely realized.

What will be the condition of the people all this time?
The stoppage of Southern trade and the cutting off of its Southern markets will bankrupt their manufacturers.
The loss of the coasting trade of the country and of the carriage of Southern staples will destroy their shipping interests and bankrupt all their Laws and Vanderbilts, great and small.
Their merchants will lose their business and go to protest; and the bankruptcy of the East will bankrupt the West.
Bankruptcy will soon be as universal as the war fever has been.
It will be a Nemesis at the heels of war.

Already their editors see these things, and the Herald mingles with its prayer for a great National Bank, still more urgent appeals for a general bankrupt law, to wipe out all debts.--They feel that they are all going to ruin together.
They want National Bank notes for a fictitious currency with which to bolster up their affairs awhile; and they want to postpone the evil day of protest by means of loans from the few hundred millions of new fictitious National Bank capital.
But, in spite of these palliating and dilatory expedients, they know the end must come, and they want a general bankrupt law to fall back softly upon.
