They want to stop payment with something still in hand for a rainy day, and they want a bankrupt law to protect them from the Sheriff.
Probably a bankrupt law wiping out all old debts will be followed by demands for an agrarian law, making a new division of property.

With a public debt, a protective tariff, a National Bank, a grand army, and all these fine agencies of magnificent speculation in full blast, the system would lack its most important part, its most beautiful and charming feature, if it lacked a general bankrupt law; and a general bankrupt law they will have.
When men are provided with unlimited means of speculation, they must be also provided with a convenient means of release from debt.
With all these great institutions in full play, the Northern genius will find itself at last in an element exactly suited to its character.
Speculatros will flourish, bankrupts will remain rich; but what will be the condition of the people, of the Government, of the country?

div3.head: The sentiment of Northwestern Virginia.
div3.p:
A gentleman who has just arrived from this section, states that no one can appreciate, without being upon the spot, the intense excitement and terrorism which exists throughout the country.
No matter what may be the social position of gentlemen, their previous association or social qualities, unless they fully coincide with the Union sentiment of the masses, they are driven from their homes by vandal Virginians, urged on to the perpetration of acts of malice and violence by the presence of the Federal troops.
Among those who have been compelled to flee from their homes and seek refuge in the mountains is ex-Governor Johnson, of Harrison county; Robert Johnston, Esq., from Clarksburg, a former Auditor of the State; Mr. Newlon and family, Senator from the Taylor district; Mr. Mortimer H. Johnston and family, from Pruntytown; Sheriff Carr, from Marion county; a brother of Gen. Haymond, of the State Council; Mr. Cooke, a citizen of Taylor, and numbers of others.

Our informant passed many of these refugees on the road, some of whom had formerly lived in Eastern Virginia, but were now being driven back by the mercenaries of abolitionism.--One of these was an old man nearly seventy years of age, who, barefoot, was traveling with his wife and family to a place of safety, driving before him his cattle and sheep and hastily-collected household goods.
In the course of the brief colloquy which ensued he remarked, "Sir, I am over sixty years of age, and have been driven from my home, but as soon as my family are in a place of safety I shall return to the house I have left, and if necessary shall defend it with my life, and if it should happen to be in ashes then I will die defending my fence.
The last drop of blood I have shall be spent in the service of Virginia."--We are glad to observe that the old spirit of seventy-six is not dead yet. There is plenty more of such stock in the State, and when the hour of battle is raging their heroism will tell its own tale.

div3.head: A gallant act.
div3.p:
--It is reported that Capt. Wm. H. Werth, of Pittsylvania, while on a solitary scouting expedition, a day or two since, in the neighborhood of Yorktown, unconsciously got inside of the enemy's pickets, and was surprised by two men in ambush, who started up in his rear and commanded him to surrender.
Capt. W. turned his horse and approached them, which led them to believe that he was about to obey the command.
This, however, he never dreamed of; but suddenly drawing his pistol, shot first one and then the other, dead.
It is stated that the two luckless Yankees were mounted upon mules.
The report seems to be well authenticated, and those who are acquainted with the brave reputation of Capt. W. can readily believe it.
A correspondent gives an account of another gallant scouting enterprise projected and carried into effect by three of our men at Yorktown.

div3.head: The affair at Philippi.
div3.p:
--We have received information, deemed reliable, which enables us to state that Mr. Thomas E. Sims, of this city, was neither killed nor wounded in the recent engagement with the Federal troops at Philippi, but is now a prisoner in the enemy's camp.
There was therefore but one killed on our side--Mr. Hanger--who died after the fight was over.

div3.head: Alabama Ordinance of Secession.
div3.p: --We have received from the publisher, Mr. L. Smith, of the Metropolitan Guards, attached to the Third Alabama Regiment, at Norfolk, a lithographic fac simile of the Alabama Ordinance of Secession, and the signatures thereto.

div3.head: Rumored landing at White House Point.
div3.p: It has been rumored on the streets for a day or two past, that the Federalists have commenced landing troops at White House Point, on the Potomac river.

div3.head: North Carolina Convention.
div3.p: --On Thursday afternoon the Convention of North Carolina adopted, by a unanimous vote, the Permanent Constitution of the Confederate States of America.

div3.head: Another resignation.
div3.p:
--Col. Taylor, Quartermaster U. S. Army, stationed at Fort Monroe, has resigned and left for New York.
Col. T. is a nephew of the late President Zachary Taylor.

div3.head: Cars for Alexandria.
div3.p: --A large number of passenger cars for the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, passed through Baltimore on Friday last; also one or two large engines.

div3.head: Death of Samuel Appleton.
div3.p: --Hon. Samuel Appleton, a prominent citizen of Boston, Mass., died on the 5th inst.
Memphis has already subscribed over $600 for the family of Jackson, the hero of Alexandria.

div3.head:
Presentation to the Maryland Guard.
speech of Hon. J. M. Mason.
div3.p: The interesting ceremony of the presentation of a Confederate flag, from the ladies of Baltimore to the members of the Maryland Guard now in Virginia, took place in the Capitol grounds, on Saturday afternoon, about half-past 6 o'clock.

Mrs. Augustus McLaughlin, the wife of one of the officers of the late U. S. Navy, who brought the flag from Baltimore, concealed as only a lady knows how, was present and received the compliments of a large number of ladies and gentlemen, who surrounded her upon the steps of the Monument, from which the address was made.
The presentation speech was made by Hon. J. M. Mason, as follows:

q.p: speech. Of Hon. J. M. Mason.

Soldiers of the Maryland Line: I am deputed to do a most grateful duty; first, in the name of Virginia, to give you an earnest and cordial welcome to the "Old Dominion;" and next, to present to you, in behalf of the ladies of Maryland, this flag.
I see, soldiers of Maryland, that you are " and ready"--the highest honor of a soldier in revolutionary times.
We all know who you are. We all know what brought you here, and we are all ready, as I trust you have experienced, to extend to you a soldier's welcome — the only welcome, indeed, that can be extended in times like these.

Your own honored State is with us heart and soul in this great controversy.
By your enterprise, your bravery, and your determined will, you have escaped from the thraldom of tyranny which envelopes that State; and you know, I know,--for I have been among its people,--we all know, that the same spirit which brought you here, actuates thousands who remain at home.
[Applause.]

I welcome you, soldiers of Maryland, upon the threshold of the second great war of independence — a war that will be transmitted by history to the future as the greatest of two wars of independence; a war that is waged against the South with less provocation, less reason, less regard to humanity and to honor, than was that waged by the mother country in 1776.

Your presence here is proof that you participate in this sentiment.
And I tell you further, my countrymen, in view of these circumstances, there is not a man among you, nor is there one belonging to a body not among you, who will dare to return to Maryland with that flag dishonored.
Not one.
I tell you further, there is not a man among you who will dare to return to Maryland, except as a soldier in victory.
Do you ask me why?
Because we are engaged in a great and holy war of self-defence.

In after ages, when history records the transactions of this epoch — when the passions of men shall have subsided, and the historian can take a calm and philosophic view of the events which have led to the present collision between the two sections, he will write that the people of the Southern States understood and protected civil liberty; and that the misguided North either did not comprehend, or abandoned it. For what have we witnessed?
The spectacle of the Chief Justice of the United States, the man who stands at the head of the principal department of the Federal Government — the man who has illustrated in his life, for more than four generations, all that adorns honor, virtue, and patriotism — a native-born citizen of your own State of Maryland--Roger B. Taney — that man has put his judicial flat of condemnation upon the Government of the United States for its shameless abandonment of the very corner-stone of our liberties.
A native Marylander, he remains at home to defend the last refuge of civil liberty against the atrocious aggressions of a remorseless tyranny.--I honor him for it; the world will honor him, posterity will honor him; and there will be inscribed upon his monument the highest tribute ever paid to a man. He has stood bravely in the breach, and interposed the unspotted arm of justice between the rights of the South and the malignant usurpation of power by the North.
There he still remains,"a cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night," to direct the welfare of our nation in this atrocious aggression upon our nation in this atrocious aggression upon our liberty.

Now, my countrymen, why are you here?
What has brought you across the border?
What is your mission to Virginia?
You tell your own tale.
You have arms in your hands; you are under a gallant leader, and you are to march under a flag honored by the ladies of your own State, worked by their own fair hands.
You are here not merely to fight our battles.
No, I am not so selfish as to presume that; but to fight the battles of civil liberty in behalf of the entire South.
And you are on a high mission.

You are not the first Marylanders who have crossed the border.
We had in the days of the first Revolution a Maryland Line, whose name has passed into history without one blot upon its fair escutcheon — a Maryland Line who illustrated upon every field in the South their devotion to the civil liberty of that day — a Maryland Line who, in the remote savannahs of the Carolinas, spilled their blood like water at Camden, at Guilford Court-House, at the Cow pens, and at Eutaw, where the last battle was fought, and the enemy finally surrendered.
They were your ancestry.
They travelled bare-footed, unclothed, without blankets or tents, and but few muskets, and you came after them.
But you have this peculiar distinction: You are volunteers in a double sense — you are volunteers for the war, and you are volunteers for the great cause of the South against the aggressions of the North.
You are no strangers; you are our neighbors.
My own home is upon the confines of your State.
I went there four weeks ago, immediately after Virginia had denounced the unholy movements in the North, to learn the spirit of your people.
I went to Frederickstown, where the Legislature were assembled, anxious to ascertain whether Virginia could rely upon you in the hour of trial.
I knew the political incubus by which your people were crushed to the earth; but such were the indications I perceived on every side, that when I returned to Virginia I unhesitatingly reported that Maryland is with the South.
I staked my word upon it as a man of principle and a man of truth.
The giant arm of the oppressor has been too strong for the time being, but the spirit is still alive, unsubdued and unrepressed.
You are here to confirm this fact by your presence.

You are in Richmond.
What is Richmond?
It is a large city — a city of gallant men and refined women; a city whose inhabitants are engaged in all the useful and honorable pursuits of life tending to the advance of civilization and prosperity.
At the present moment, however, Richmond is a huge camp, where but one mind, one heart and one determination animates every occupant, man, woman and child.
[Applause.] Our wives, mothers,--and I appeal to the ladies if I may not also say our sweethearts,--have entered into it with a zest which shows that their hearts and affections are fully in the work.
You will have no child's play.
There is no time now for vain boasting.
I confide as much as I can in the prowess of the men of this section, and you will be false to the fame of your fathers if you are not victors; but your enemy relies upon mere brute force.--There are doubtless brave soldiers among whom it will be hard to conquer, but you will remember that you are fighting for your fathers, mothers and firesides.
They are mercenaries fighting for pay, you are men fighting for your homes and rights.
All you require is subsistence.
"Give us," you say, "the means of living, the arms to fight with, and show us the enemy." [Applause.] It may be that in the providence of war, not one among all those who are before me will return.
You have come here if necessary to lay your lives upon the altar of your country, and I feel assured that every man will do his duty.

I will tell you an incident connected with the Alabama troops.
They were attended by a minister of the Gospel, who was a guest at my house.
He told me that he had with him a purse of gold which had been given to him by the parents of two young men in the ranks with the injunction that it should be sacredly preserved during the war, unless his sons should fall upon the field of battle.
Then, said the father, "Give them a Christian burial." There was a patriot father who had devoted his sons to the service of his country, and that man does not stand alone.

Such is the object with which you have engaged in this war. The true duty of the soldier is not merely to fight a battle or kill an enemy.
He has also to endure the trials of the camp; the weariness of the forced march; the vigilance of the day and night; the restraints of discipline, and the patience to bear with his discomforts and disappointments.
This is the real test of courage, and he who comes out of the war with the reputation of having thus done his duty through sunshine and through storm, is the true man and the thorough soldier.

But I will not detain you longer, except to discharge the grateful duty which remains, of presenting to you in behalf of the ladies of Baltimore, this beautiful banner.
There it is unfurled before you for the first time.
There are emblazoned the fifteen stars of the Southern States, looking prospectively to the day when they will all be with us!
The star of Maryland is among them, and the women of your State have put it there, confiding it to your safe-keeping.
Look upon it as a sacred trust.
In passing through the storm of battle, it may be tattered and soiled, but I believe I can say that you will bring it back without a spot of dishonor upon it. But you are not only to return that flag here — you are to take it back to Baltimore.
[Cheers and cries of "we will."] It came here in the hands of the fair lady who stands by my side, who brought it through the camp of the enemy, with a woman's fortitude, courage and devotion to our cause; and you are to take it back to Baltimore, unfurl it in your streets, and challenge the applause of your citizens.
[Applause.]

div3.p: Accompanying the flag is this inscription:

q.p: "The ladies of Baltimore present this flag of the Confederate States of American to the soldiers composing the Maryland Regiment now serving in Virginia, as a slight testimonial of the esteem in which their valor, their love of right, and de
termination to uphold true constitutional liberty are approved, applauded and appreciated by the wives and daughters of the Monumental city."

div3.p: Your ladies will always have a little poetry and it closes as follows:

q.p: "Take this banner, and beneath the battle cloud's encircling wreath.
Guard it till our homes are free.

Guard it!
God will prosper thee."

div3.p: The flag was then handed to Col. Thomas, of the Maryland Volunteers, who, with Mrs. McLaughlin upon his arm, advanced to the front of the line, and in a few remarks confided it to the keeping of the standard-bearer of the battalion.

Cheers were then given for the ladies of Baltimore, the State of Virginia and three times three for the Southern Confederacy.
The battalion then went through a series of evolutions and left the Capitol grounds on a "double quick."

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
Affairs in Petersburg.
div3.p:
The 39th Regiment of Virginia Militia, Col. Brockett, was drilled to-day under the inspection of Brigade Inspector, Col. Potts, of Greensville.
Col. P. is a very fine officer, and as there will be a weekly drill, the men will doubtless make good progress in the use of arms.
As they were marched through the streets they were accompanied by two of the regularly organized Home companies; but as these last are regularly drilled, they are very properly exempted from militia duty.

There was more curiosity to see the Louisiana Zouaves yesterday, on their passage through the city, than I have seen manifested on any former occasion.
Judging from the crowds at the depot, the squads on the streets, and the crowding of every room affording a good view, they were doubtless subjected to the critical observations of almost every person, male and female, within the limits of the city.

The ladies have taken the matter in hand, and have raised a considerable sum in aid of the Jackson fund.
In fact, they are so zealous in the public cause, that their activity is exerted in every way in which it can be rendered available.
They are busily engaged in making tents and various articles of soldiers' clothing; food for the troops who are en route is prepared under their direction; and they offer to make mattresses for their accommodation when they are detained here over night, as not unfrequently happens.
All honor to the women of Virginia!
Within the few past days we have had copious showers of rain, which have been most acceptable to the farmers, whose crops had begun to suffer from the effects of the drought.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
from the First Howitzer Company.
div3.p: It would not be inappropriate to begin this note in coffee and sugar style, thus: "Howitzers dull and on the decline," just as one says "ashes sprightly, with an upward tendency." Otherwise the members of this company are at present mere straws, awaiting the wind.--This passiveness of being, this rooting and wallowing, have changed a heretofore active set of youths into one of the laziest crowds going.

The Howitzers drill well at the gun; but, in truth's name, it must be admitted that two things they do not seem to fancy: answering the matutinal roll-call and marching.
They would eat whole crocodiles rather than leave straw at 4 A. M., and take batteries from the enemy rather than march in a straight line.
They seem to have no particular desire of "keeping the step," hence the company's shins are growing, fare sumptuous, eating as laziness eats.
But while stating these little facts, it is not wished to be inferred that at the appointed hour the Howitzers will be behind in anything, or prove a bad investment of the State; bien au contraine.

Another artillery company now here is the "Lynchburg," Capt. Latham-a very fine one. Capt. L. is the most attractive fellow on the ground — all des all beckon him for visits, as of wit to Mar's valor.

div3.head: Gen. Beauregard's Proclamation.
div3.p: Gen. Beauregard has issued the following proclamation to the people of the Loudoun, Fairfax and Prince William.

A reckless and unprincipled tyrant has invaded your soil.
Abraham Lincoln.
regardless of all moral, legal and constitutional restrains, has thrown his Abolition among you, who are murdering and imprisoning your citizens, confiscating and destroying your property, and committing other acts of violence and outrage, too shocking and revolting to humanity to be enumerated.
All rules of civilized warfare are abandoned, and they proclaim by their acts, if not on their banners, that their war-cry is "Beauty and Booty." All that is dear to man — your honor, and that of your wives and daughters — your fortunes and your lives, are involved in this momentous contest.

In the name, therefore, of the constituted authorities of the Confederate States--in the sacred cause of constitutional liberty and self-government, for which we are contending — in behalf of civilization and humanity itself, I, G. T. Beauregard, Brigadier-General of the Confederate States, commanding at Camp Pickens, Manassas Junction, do make this my proclamation, and invite and enjoin you, by every consideration dear to the hearts of freemen and patriots, by the name and memory of your revolutionary fathers, and by the purity and sanctity of your domestic firesides, to rally to the standard of your State and country, and by every means in your power compatible with honorable warfare, to drive back and expel the invaders from your land.
I conjure you to be true and loyal to your country and her legal and constitutional authorities, and especially to be vigilant of the movements and acts of the enemy, so as to enable you to give the earliest authentic information at these headquarters, or to the officers under my command.
I desire to assure you that the utmost protection in my power will be extended to you all. (Signed,) G. T. Beauregard,
Brig. Gen'l Comd'g.
Official: Thomas Jordan,
Act'g Ass't Adj't Gen'l.

div3.head: News from Washington.
div3.p: --A Washington dispatch says:

q.p:
The steam vessels now lying the Navy-Yard have received orders to prepare for the transportation of troops, and to be ready to leave at a moment's warning.
Most of them keep up a little steam day and night.

The New York Fifth, Col. Schwarzaelder, have no camping equipage, and the regiment is well entitled to the few days of rest it is now enjoying.
Bad feeling prevails among the officers of New York Ninth.
Unarmed members of the First German Rifle regiments are being daily attacked by rowdies, some of whom are connected with the militia companies of the District.

Gen. Scott is in receipt of positive information about the long-missing Beauregard, and expects him to stand his ground for a fight, and that the Harper's Ferry forces will probably retreat to that point.

We have late and direct news from Manassas Gap to the effect that the enemy have five batteries of heavy calibre well in position there.
Also, a lighter battery of field-pieces, and a third of heavy cannon planted upon the higher grounds commanding the approach to that point.
Magruder is in command of the artillery, and Col. Abersham's North Carolina troops are encamped there.
In addition to these, there are at present three or four regiments from Alabama, Virginia and Kentucky, and two from South Carolina.
The number of troops from our side who will now move upon this position is not less than 12,000.

div3.head: Maryland Legislature.
div3.p: --We copy the following from the proceedings of the Maryland Legislature on Thursday last:

q.p: O. Horsey, Esq., the commissioner appointed by this body to enter into negotiations with the authorities of Virginia for the protection of citizens of Maryland from injury in person and property by any unadvised acts of the military forces of that State, and to obtain compensation for any injury already done, submitted a report setting forth that he had obtained from Gov. Letcher a distinct disavowal of the acts of the Virginia military in seizing the property of citizens in Maryland, accompanied by an earnest expression of regret for such acts of lawlessness and of an earnest desire to maintain harmonious relations with our State.

He appointed a commissioner to return to Maryland with him, and to investigate the nature and extent of the damages inflicted.
This investigation resulted in the adjustment of the only claim against the State of Virginia, of which they were apprised, that of Charles F. Wenner, who was paid $1,693.75.

The report expresses the belief that the dams of the canal which are in Virginia will be protected by the authorities of that State, and that the interests of Maryland in this great work will not be materially jeopardized.

div3.head: Affairs at Alexandria.
div3.p: --A letter from Alexandria, published in the Baltimore Sun, says:

q.p:
"Military matters have been quiet here for several days, only one company being in town, except the artillery and cavalry at the upper end of King street. The rest of the force is on the west side of Shuter's Hill, with a few at Cloud's Mill, a few miles further, no troops being South of Cameron Run.
About 200 Irish laborers occupy the Lyceum here, who are daily engaged in fortifying Shuter's Hill."

div3.head: More resignations of Naval Office.
div3.p: --Captain George N. Hollins, of Greytown fame, Lieutenant Joseph N. Barney, Gunner S. W. Lovett, Carpenter M. Bain, Salimaker William M. Mahoney, Midshipman Hodge, and two other Midshipmen, just arrived from the Mediterranean on the war steamer Susquehanna, have tendered their several resignations, which will not be accepted, the Star takes it for granted; but, instance, their names are likely to be struck from the United States naval list.

div4.p:
A scouting party, composed of three men — Jno. S. Scott, of Louisa, an old ranger; Joseph Phillips, and old Uncle Ben--came upon a party of nine Black Republicans, belonging to the Fifth Regiment of New York Volunteers, within two miles of Hampton, on yesterday.
The vandals fired upon our small party without injuring any one, when our men charged upon them, killed one, wounded another, and took one prisoner, together with several muskets and a five shooter.
The same day they procured two traitors — a man by the name of Kimball and his son-in-law.
As the scouts approached where they were they fled, but when told that they were friends, they said that if they had known they were Yankees they would not have run. They were asked if they knew where any secession men were, and they said yes, and would show them through the woods.
When they got them out from the road, our men told them they had use for them at Yorktown, and took them prisoners.
They reached here this morning, together with the Black Republican.
You may expect to hear of the clearing of the road of the robbers that have infested it since the landing of troops at Fort Monroe and Newport News.

We are still very busy at Yorktown.--Yesterday, a man came upon two Yankees, and they asked him if he knew where any Secessionists were.
He told them "yes." He went along with them, and suddenly took up his gun, and then told them if they moved he would shoot them; he marched them into York, and, having previously ascertained from them where some more Yankees were, he got two men to go with him, and started off, came up with them, eight in all, killed one, wounded another and took one prisoner; the other Yankees ran, and that is the way we are going to whip them all through the war.

This morning two companies of cavalry passed through town, destination unknown; and yesterday evening two companies of infantry — nobody knows where they have gone; the soldiers were laughing and cracking jokes all the way.

The hellish vagabonds — I can call them nothing else — are committing all sorts of outrages in the vicinity of Hampton.
They do not seem to have any respect for chastity, as I hear they commit outrages even upon the persons of unprotected females.
A portion of the Third Regiment came up from York night before last, and from what I can learn they had a hard time.
They are, never the less, in fine spirits, and anxious for a brush.

People are still coming in from the lower part of the Peninsula, being driven away by scouting parties from Fortress Monroe.
We will soon stop that.
Col. Ewell is as busy as a bee; he is going all the time, and never seems to be tired.
Our soldiers at the camp drill every other hour, and then have a dress parade at sunset.
It is very fatiguing, as I myself can testify.
We don't mind it, though, if we can only get a pop at the "critters."

div3.head: From New York.
div3.p: --A letter from New York, of Thursday's date, says:

q.p:
The letters for the Southern States, at the post-office on Wednesday, numbered 480.
The number has not decreased to-day.
The Councils of Bishops composing the Roman Catholic Province of New York, resumed their deliberations this morning in the sacristy of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The two exiled Prelates from Mexico, with the Promoter, Secretaries and Notaries were present.

The morning was devoted to the consideration of several propositions relative to the government of the Church, and in the evening session they were referred to the several committees of theologians, embracing about twenty clergymen, for examination.
The Council then adjourned till Friday morning.

The monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held this afternoon.
Mr. Ruggler a paper on the substitution of the shred of flax for cotton as an article of manufacture.
The paper was laid over.
Resolution were offered that the Chamber inquire into present defenceless condition of New York harbor.

McChesney's Zouaves are not off yet. Half of the Regiment are on board the transport State of Georgia, and the remainder are "hangin" about town.
It is very probable, however, that they will leave to-morrow morning.

div3.head: French Legion.
div3.p: --We copy the following from the New Orleans Picayune, of the 5th inst.:

q.p:
It is not generally known that we have already established among us a French Legion, composed entirely of citizens of France.
Not wishing to lose their rights as French citizens, they have, through the French Consul of this city, effected the following agreement with the Governor of the State:

"We, the undersigned officers, non-commissioned officers and privates of the French Legion, all subjects of the Empire of France, agree by these presents, as soon as our officers shall have received their commissions, to hold ourselves constantly in readiness to obey the orders of the Governor of the State of Louisiana and our superior officers, for all active service that may be required of us, within the limits of the city of New Orleans."

The legion already comprises five companies, which have been raised within a short time.
It is not astonishing, however, when we consider the numerous French foreign population among us, and whose ties and attachments to Louisiana are so great, that in such a cause they cannot remain neutral.
Should their services be necessary, we can rely on those gallant sons of France for their bravery and chivalry, in the protection of our city.

div3.head: New York financial matters.
div3.p:
--Virginia 6's sold at 44 and North Carolinas at 52 in New York last Friday.
The Journal of Commerce, of Thursday afternoon, says:

q.p:
The tone of the private letters from England, even more than the public advices, have created some disquiet in the market, and have reduced the hope which many have entertained of a reaction in public sentiment that should be more favorable to our side of the contest in this country.
It is not yet too late, perhaps, for such a reaction, but the chances may be diminished by the evidences of hostility to the Western country of which certain parties on this side have given so much proof during the last few days.
This exhibition has caused more concern in our financial circles than any other aspect of the questions now exciting the public mind, and the business is very limited.
Foreign exchange is nominally the same, but there is a better currency for select commercial signatures.
The stock market is better in a fery few particulars, but is generally heavy and lower.

div3.head: How they discipline their troops.
div3.p:
--A letter from Chambersburg to the Philadelphia Ledger would indicate that the officer in command should have an appointment under the Inquisition for his dexterity in inventing modes of torture.
He says:

q.p:
A new mode of punishment has been inaugurated here by Brigadier General Thomas, that is, to make the refractory ones walk round in a circle for several hours, carrying a heavy rail.
In some instances the punishment lasts for twenty-four hours, during which the men must neither stop, eat nor sleep!
The punishment is fearful.

div3.head: The schooner Lynchburg.
div3.p: --We find the following in the New York Post, of the 4th instant:

q.p:
The schooner Lynchburg, from Rio Janeiro, owned in Richmond, Virginia, arrived at quarantine this morning under charge of Sailing-master Gordon and a prize crew.
She was captured off Cape Henry on the 30th ultimo by the flagship Cumberland, Captain Pendergast, and sent immediately to this port.
She has on board a choice cargo of coffee and other Brazilian productions.
The Lynchburg is at present in charge of the prize-master, and remains subject to the order of Messrs. Elliot and Ohren, Prize Commissioners, till libelled and delivered to the Marshal.

div3.head: From Kanawha
div3.p: --The Kanawha Republican, of the 4th inst., says:

q.p: We learn upon the best authority that a regiment of troops are at this time encamped at the foot of the hill back of Gallipolis, O., their presence being for the protection of the town.
The rumor that prevailed in our town, last week, that a large body of troops from Ohio were about to occupy Point Pleasant, was without the slightest foundation in fact.
The people on the other side of the Ohio may be assured that, in case of an invasion, or any wanton assault or interference from them, the people of this Valley will be a unit in its defence.

div3.head: Another prize taken.
div3.p: --A Savannah dispatch to the Charleston Courier says:

q.p:
The fine first-class ship Sebasticook has been taken possession of by the Collector of this port as a prize to the Confederate States, she having remained beyond the time granted to foreign vessels to leave for their homes.
Had the Collector not been as prompt in performing the duty, other eyes were upon the ship, and she would have been well taken care of before this.
She was owned in Bath, Maine.
Efforts, I learn, were made to change her papers, and thus make an English vessel of her; but that trick would not take.

div3.head: Singular Detention of a Railroad Train.
div3.p:
--A conductor on the Nashville Railroad informed us, a few days ago, that his train was stopped by an emigration of army worms crossing the track.
They were over an inch thick on the track, and the wheels of the locomotive, when it came upon their midst, whirled round and round, as if the track was covered with ice, and would not move an inch forward.
The train was backed out and the track cleared of the worms with shovels.--Louisville Courier, June 1st.

div3.head: Death of Mr. John L. Smither.
div3.p:
--We regret to announce the death of this gentleman, which occurred about half-past 4 o'clock on Saturday evening. In the Dispatch of that day we gave a brief account of his having been accidentally shot on Friday evening by a pistol ball discharged from a Colt's revolver in the hands of Mr. Joseph Brummel, at the shooting gallery, corner of Main and 14th streets. We learn that every expedient that human ingenuity could devise was tried in vain to preserve the life of Mr. Smither.
His remains were conveyed to their last resting place Sunday evening.

The name of the soldier who broke his leg and badly bruised himself on Friday by falling down the dumb waiter at the tin and sheet iron establishment of C. D. Yale & Co., on 13th street, is J. C. Wicks, a member of the Louisa Grays, Captain W. J. Sargeant.
His injuries are such that several weeks must necessarily elapse before he will be in a condition to bear removal to his home in the vicinity of the Green Spring, in Louisa.
In the meantime we hope that our citizens will see that he does not lack those little delicacies and attentions so needful to the sick.

div3.head: A Turfman in the field.
div3.p:
--Col. T. G. Bacon, of the 7th South Carolina Regiment, arrived here on Saturday last, with his command, which is one of the finest bodies of men in the service.
The Colonel looks well, and — as usual--"can't be bluffed."
There are quite a number of turfmen here at present, all of whom will find Col. Bacon and the Seventh near the Fairfield Race Track.

Sergeant Sullivan and Corporal Anderson, of the Thomas Artillery, were badly bruised Saturday evening by being thrown from one of the batteries by the capers of two unruly horses, as the company was proceeding from the parade ground to their encampment.
One of the horses was badly wounded, and a cannon was pitched down a declivity.

The Police arrested a number of persons Saturday night and Sunday for petty infractions of law, some dozen or more of whom it was deemed proper to retain till this morning.
The bachanalians were largely represented in the list of arrests.
Drunkenness is on the increase.

Thursday, the 13th, is set apart for an occasion of Fasting and Prayer by the recommendation of the Congress of the Confederate States.
Our impression is that the day will be very generally observed everywhere within the limits of the Confederacy.

div3.head: Green tea.
div3.p:
--A friend handed us a small bunch of green tea--the bona fide green tea of China — grown in Hyde county, which we have tried and find excellent.
With the exception of a slight fresh green taste, it was decidedly superior to the tea brought all the way from the Celestial Empire.
And this taste, we are satisfied, was the result of its not being sufficiently cured.
We know not how much can be grown to the acre, nor the time, care and expense necessary to cultivate and raise it. But we suppose that it might be successfully and profitably grown and prepared for market.
As one of the luxuries that people will have, though wars may come and high tariffs have to be paid, and though the money must be sent out of the country, it would be well to give it a fair trial.
We hope the gentleman who cultivated that that we drank with pleasure will continue to cultivate it, and others will try. Let us make everything at home that we can profitably make.--Washington (N. C.) Dis.

div3.head: Armstrong gun and Enfield Rifle.
div3.p:
--We have seen it stated in several papers that an Armstrong rifled gun, imported from England, was used against Fort Sumter.
Now, this is a mistake; Armstrong guns are manufactured exclusively for the British Government, and cannot be sold to private parties.
It was an English (Blakely) rifle cannon imported from Liverpool that was used at Charleston.

We have also seen it stated in several papers that Enfield rifles, purchased in England, have arrived here for arming our volunteers.
This is also a mistake.
The rifles made at Enfield are all for the British army, because the works belong to the Government.
Such rifles cannot be sold, to private parties, nor obtained upon any account from England.--The British rifled muskets that have been imported are equally as good as those made at Enfield, because they are similar in pattern though they are manufactured by private gun smiths.--Scientific American.

div3.head: Departure for Europe.
div3.p:
--The Cunard mail steamer Persia, Capt. Judkins, sailed from New York on Wednesday for Liverpool, with 200 passengers, among whom are J. A. Dela Fuente, Mexican Minister to France, and family; August Belmont and family; Baron Rothschild; Hon. Mr. Bodisco, of the Russian legation, and family; Rev. Bishop Janes, of New York, and his brother, the Rev. E. L. Janes.
The Bishop goes out to visit the several Methodist missions stationed in Europe.
He expects to preside at the German Mission Conference which meets at Bremen on the 20th inst. He will also visit the stations in Germany, Switzerland, Denmark and Norway.

div3.head: An English pugilist injured.
div3.p:
--Tom Sayers visited Galashiels, Eng., on the 18th ult., with Howes & Cushing's Circus.
While proceeding on horseback to the place of exhibition in the evening, the horse shied at the flapping of the canvas of the circus, and he was thrown to the ground and pretty severely injured.
Medical aid was promptly given and when he had recovered from his faint, he stated that he felt weaker and more out of order than he did after his encounter with Heenan.
No bones were, we understand, broken; nevertheless, the pugilist sustained several severe bruises, and on the 19th he was confined to his bed.

div3.head: The New York and Virginia Masons.
div3.p: --The Grand Lodge of New York have adopted resolutions declaring that "the decree of non-intercourse recently promulgated by the Grand Lodge of Virginia as against this Grand Lodge should not and does not exonerate the Masons hailing from this jurisdiction now or hereafter to be on the roll of Virginia or elsewhere from the performance of those high and holy Masonic duties towards Masons owing allegiance to the Grand Lodge of Virginia, which are imperatively cast upon them by their vows made in the craft, the laws of God and the dictates of humanity." A sharp discussion took place on the resolutions.

div3.head: Cotton Statistics
div3.p:
--The latest reports from Great Britain show that the consumption of cotton for the current crop year has diminished an average of 5,200 bales per week, or 270,400 bales for the year, owing to the high price and the commercial depression.
The stock in Liverpool, May 24, was 1,112,000 bales, sufficient to supply the weekly consumption at the last average (43,600 bales) for more than 25 weeks. Besides, there were at sea, bound for Liverpool, 120,000 bales from the United States and 290,000 bales from Bombay, or supplies for nine weeks more--thirty-five weeks in all.

div3.head: Death of a venerable Priest.
div3.p:
--The Rev. J. J. Vital, one of the ablest priests of this diocese, departed this life on the 25th ult., at the Sisters Infirmary in Louisville, after a lingering and painful illness of six months duration.
Father Vital was about sixty-five years old. He was ordained in Montpelier France, 1st October, 1818.--Louis.
Courier.

div3.head: A liberal patriot.
div3.p: --Hon. J. D. Waters wealthy planter on Brazos river, Texas, and an uncle of W. W. Boyce, has tendered to the Southern Confederacy the entire proceeds of his crop, (after deducting sufficient to carry on his plantation,) amounting to twelve hundred bags of cotton, five hundred hogsheads of sugar, and thirty thousand bushels of corn.

div3.head: Prizes to be released.
div3.p: --A letter was received in New York on Wednesday, from Commodore Breeze, United States Navy, informing the United States District Attorney by the authority of the Secretary of State, that the prize vessels Octavio, Wm. Henry and E. Hall, were to be surrendered to their respective owners and claimants.

div3.head: Fatal Accident.
div3.p:
--On Saturday night week, the express train on the N. C. R. R.
ran over the body of a man named John Corbett, killing him instantly.
It is supposed he was intoxicated at the time.

div3.head: Arrest for treason.
div3.p: --Mr. Summers, for twenty years book-keeper of the Insurance Bank of Augusta, Ga., has been arrested, charged with writing treasonable letters North.

div3.head: British war vessels in the Roads.
div3.p: --We learned yesterday that a large British frigate had arrived in the Roads, but were unable to get further particulars.--Norfolk Argus, 8th.
A writer in the Atlanta Confederacy proposes that the name of "Confederate States of Virginia" be given to the whole of the Southern States.
Two locomotives for the Northern Government passed through Baltimore on Friday last, to be used on the Orange and Alexandria Railroad.
The stock of cotton at Savannah, on hand and on shipboard not cleared, 1st instant, was of Uplands 8,152 bales, of Sea Islands 1,775 bales.
Foley, who shot a fellow soldier in Washing, has had his sentence commuted to twenty-one years imprisonment.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 19, Number 133, page 3.

div3.head:
Latest News
by
Special Express.
div3.p:
We received, last evening, Baltimore papers of Friday last, from which we copy the following late news touching the operations of the Federal army.
Due allowance must be made for every expression emanating from Northern sources.
News from Fortress Monroe.

The steamer Adelaide reached Baltimore rom Old Point on Friday morning. Among her passengers was Col. Jos. Segar, who proceeded onto Washington on business connected with his property near the fortress and at Hampton, which is now in the occupancy of the U. S. troops.
The Baltimore Republican gives the following by the arrival:

Yesterday afternoon the large steamship Alabama reached Old Point with the Fourth Regiment of Artillery, from New York.
They numbered one thousand men, and literally crowded the ship, fifty or sixty lying on the pilot house.
They were received with three cheers by the crew of the Cumberland, and the band of the latter struck up a National air.--The Regiment would encamp beyond Hampton.
Mrs. Major Gwynn, of Raleigh, N. C., has just left that place, and came up through the flag of truce.

She had a good opportunity of seeing the Confederate forces, and declares that the road all the way through is lined with regiments upon regiments of men well armed, and determined to fight for their State and for the entire South.
She gives a particular account of the location of many batteries well planted, but which we are not at liberty to publish at present.
The Harriet Lane, Capt. Faunce's brag ship, which made such an inglorious retreat from Pig Point battery, is lying near the Cumberland, seeming afraid to budge.
The Baltimore Sun, of Friday, has the following by the arrival of the steamer Georgianna, from Old Point:

div4.head: Letter from on Board the Harriet Lane.
div4.p: I seize a moment to inform you that the "Harriet Lane" has just exchanged shots with the enemy, who were strongly posted in a battery of six or seven guns, at Pig Point, where the Nansemond comes into the James River.

The engagement lasted three-quarters of an hour, beginning at 8 35 a. m., and was quite brisk, some thirty shot having been thrown by us and upwards of fifty by the Confederates.
Some of their shots passed a long way over us, and others again fell short.

The Harriet Lane received one round shot forward, near our long 32 pounder.
It struck the shot tub, making a great scattering of splinters and shot, and wounding five of the men--three of them severely — and passing entirely through the vessel.
Another round shot passed through the fore rigging and grazing the foremast went out through the starboard bulwarks.

Their guns were well served, and had they had our range more to their satisfaction, would have hulled us every shot.
As far as we could judge, they had some seven guns, all but two of them heavy pieces — say 32 to 42 pounders; the others howitzers or rifled cannon.

When our men found that their desire of meeting the enemy in earnest was to be at length gratified, they gave three cheers and went into their work with a will.
The officers have expressed themselves delighted with the men's conduct, and are pleased to have had an opportunity of proving the "Harriet Lane" to be something more than a Prince's pleasure yacht or a dispatch vessel.

div3.head:
[Correspondence of Associated press]
Fortress MonroeJune 6.
div3.p: Another regiment is hourly expected, and will proceed to Newport News.
The Naval Brigade is fast diminishing.--Some two hundred have returned to New York, and nearly as many have enlisted in other regiments now here.

Those of the brigade who refuse to labor are sent over to the Rip Raps.
These are facetiously called "Butler's Coast Guard."
The gun-boat Quaker City brought up another valuable prize, and the Harriet Lane also captured a small sloop last night.
An important military movement is on the point of execution, of which it would be imprudent now to speak particularly.
More about the Fight at Philippi.

Grafton, June 4--10 P. M.--A messenger has just returned from Philippi, having left there at three o'clock this afternoon.
A medical examination of Col. Kelly's wounds has been made by doctors, who pronounce them not mortal.
His chances for recovery are considered favorable.
He was in good spirits.
The troops are still concentrated at Philippi, and large cargoes of provisions were left here for them to-day.
William J. Willey is a prisoner, and at this time is quite ill. Valuable papers were found in his possession.

The Wheeling Intelligencer of Wednesday says: "We learned yesterday evening, from various telegraphic dispatches, that the bridges recently burned by the Secessionists, and more recently repaired by our folks, were washed away yesterday by the high waters."

Grafton, June 6.--Col. Kelly, who bore so active a part in the surprise of the Secessionists at Philippi, arrived here last night.--There is an improvement in his condition, though he is not considered out of danger.

Major Loring, of Wheeling, has been arrested on the charge of treason.
Sundry Secessionists have been released on taking the oath of allegiance.
The Union feeling is predominant, and volunteer companies are being raised throughout Western Virginia.

.Cincinnati, June 7.--Col. Kelly is better, and hopes continue to be indulged of his recovery.
The Federal force now at Philippi is 3,000 strong.
Fifteen dead bodies of the Confederate troops have been found in a thicket near their camp (!!) A party had hid there, and the Indianians fired into the thicket to dislodge them.
From Chambershurg, Pennsylvania.Chambersburg, June 5. --Only 100 out of the 200 baggage wagons, necessary for transportation purposes of the whole force have as yet arrived.

Two regiments of volunteers and five companies of cavalry will advance as far south as Hagerstown to-night or to-morrow.
The 7th, 8th, and 10th regiments will leave Camp Slifer as soon as the rain abates, and will encamp ten miles below, near Greencastle.

Perfect plans of all the cross and leading country roads leading to Virginia in Maryland are in possession of General Patterson, and copies are being rapidly made for distribution among the field officers.
The troops are very impatiently awaiting the forward movement.

Colonel Rowley's thirteenth Pennsylvania regiment arrived from York last night.
The sixteenth is expected from the same point to-day.

Two men, belonging to company E, second cavalry regiment, yesterday left their camp with a pass, came to town, put on citizens clothes and started southward.
They were arrested by the picket guard of the Scott Legion, ten miles South, and brought back.--They are lodged in prison.
Each of them had three pistols.

Through a scout sent to the Maryland Heights, overlooking Harper's Ferry, who returned to day, we have a report that there are fewer troops upon the heights than one week ago. He says positively that there was only two guns in the battery, and that it can be stormed with but little loss of life, and the guns turned upon the Ferry.
He explored three routes by which the troops can approach within three hundred yards of the battery, and then by a rush carry the guns at the point of the bayonet.

A forward movement is evidently contemplated for to-morrow.
The advance will consist of Col. Thomas' cavalry, which will march overland.
The other corps and regiments will be thrown forward rapidly.
Army Movements — No Advance yet on Fairfax Court-House.
Washington, June 7. --The numerous rumors put in circulation since Saturday last of a march of Federal troops upon Fairfax Court-House, were without foundation.
No changes have been made excepting in the position of Regiments on the defensive works in the course of construction.

The troops labor hard during the day and sleep soundly at night, disturbed only by an occasional exchange of shots between their guards and the Virginia scouts.
The Federal troops farthest in advance is a force of several companies of the 2d cavalry, the senior officer of which is Capt. Brackett, who has seen much service and established a high character for vigilance.
Negro Soldiers.

Baltimore June 7.--Among the 9th Regiment from Pennsylvania, which passed through this city yesterday, were a number of negro soldiers, who, by their constant association with the whites, had become most impertinent and overbearing.
As the regiment was passing along Cathedral street, near the Bolton depot, a lady standing upon the sidewalk was so disgusted with the familiarity of the negroes among the men that she gave vent to her indignation in a rather bitter remark, when an impudent yellow scoundrel turned toward her and applied the epithet of "Go to h--1, you d — n white hussey." The remark was distinctly heard by his comrades, who instead of beating him to the earth as men would have done, laughed heartily at his impudence.
The villain was discovered by several citizens afterward, and had it not been for the police he would have been dragged out regardless of consequences.

div3.head: General telegraphic Dispatches.
div3.p: The following comes through the medium of the Northern Associated Press:
Dispatches to the Navy Department.

Washington,June 6th. --The Navy Department to-day received dispatches from Lieut. Craven, commanding the steamer Crusader, dated Key West, May 27th. He says: On the 14th the steamer Swannee, late Pampero, arrived there from New Orleans, under the proclamation of blockade, as also the order of the Secretary of the Treasury, for a clearance to ports of the seceded States, and he refused to permit her to return to New Orleans.
He offered to clear her for New York, which offer was declined.
He therefore detained her for the use of the Government, and the captain relinquished the command.
The Swannee belongs to the same company who loaned their steamer Rusk to the parties who seized the Star of the West.

Lieut. Craven confessed some degree of satisfaction in being thus able to inflict on that party a retaliation for thus using their own steamer.
Lieut. Duncan was placed in command, and sent in search for the bark Majestic, about which great anxiety was felt.
He fell in with her at sea, and conducted her into Key West.

On the 23d, an order having been received from Col. Brown for troops and stores, for Fort Pickens, Lieutenant Duncan sailed in the Swannee with seventy soldiers and a full freight of stores of various kinds for that Fort.

Not withstanding the Southern reports to the contrary, it appears from Capt. Adams' letter to the Navy Department, dated May 20th, that great preparations had been made for an attack on Fort Pickens, which at that time was hourly expected.
He dispatched the Wyandotte to Key West to bring down troops, and afterwards placed her in position where she could render the most aid. Previous to that time Capt. Adams informed Gen. Bragg that the port was strongly blockaded, and that vessels would be dealt with according to the laws against violating blockade.

Gen. Bragg, in reply, said he considered this notification a virtual acknowledgment of national existence, and of the independence of the Confederate States.
He asked Captain Adams to please consider the harbor closed against all boats and vessels of the United States, as he should permit none to enter except Captain Adams' dispatch boat, under a white flag.

Com. Stribling, commanding the East India squadron, reports, under date of May 29, good health prevailing on board all the vessels composing the squadron.
He says to the Secretary of the Navy. "The opening of the Yangtsze to British trade will make me hasten my arriving at Shanghai, and as soon after my arrival there as I can make the necessary preparations, I intend to go up the Yanktsze as far as Nanking in my flag-ship, taking the Dacotah and Saginaw with me at Nanking.
I hope to come to an agreement with the insurgent chiefs to permit the free navigation of the river by American ships.
The insurgents have command of both branches of the river from the vicinity of Ching Kiang to the neighborhood of Hankin, and it is very important to secure their good will, otherwise our ships could not navigate the river in safety."
Arms Stored at Havana for the Confederates.

Washington,June 6.--It having been reported that a large number of arms had been stored in Havana, under the protection of the British flag, for the Confederate States, Consul Shufeldt was directed to inquire into the subject.

A letter has just been received from him, in which he says the matter had previously engaged his attention.
He had found that all munitions of war brought there as merchandize must be immediately deposited in a Government warehouse, and are sold then only by express permit from the Captain General himself.
It would be impossible to land the number of rifles specified — namely, 200,000--without the knowledge of the Government, and the authorities, on their own account, would be extremely unwilling to permit the illicit importation of such a large amount of arms to the Island of Cuba; and besides, he had the assurance of the Captain General that it would not be permitted.

A Spanish house had ordered in Belgium 70,000 rifles, with a view to speculation in the present crisis; but, as this house has failed, the Consul presumes the order will not be filled.
He is under the impression that a few of the rejected muskets of the Spanish army have been sold there at public auction — say ten thousand--and that these are the only arms which have gone from Havana to our Southern ports for the use of the Secessionists.
Post-Office Discontinued — Appointments, &c.
Washington, June 6. --The Postmaster at Memphis having refused to distribute mail matter sent to his office, the Postmaster General has directed the following order to be issued

"Post-Office Department--Appointment Office. The post-office at Memphis, Tenn., is discontinued.
The Postmaster General orders all postmasters to forward to the dead-letter office at Washington all mail matter which is directed to that office.
"The above order has been issued from the Post-Office Department this day, June 6, 1861.
(Signed) "John A. Kasson,
The President has appointed Jonas A. Clark District Attorney, and James O. Sutton, Marshal, for the Western District of Missouri.
The Navy Department to-day received a notification of the resignation of Capt. Hollins and Lieut. Joseph N. Barney, both of Maryland, who have just returned from the Mediterranean.
The Post-Office Department has received a copy of a circular issued by Postmaster General Reagan, of the Confederate States.

The Naval Brigade.Washington,June 6. --Col. Bartlett, of the Naval Brigade, will return to Old Point this afternoon.
He states that General Butler now has the orders of the President and Secretary of War to accept the brigade with the full complement of twelve hundred men and eighty officers, exactly as ordered by the President on the 22d ult.
If other statements are to be believed, Col. Bartlett's information is incorrect as to the number of the brigade to be mustered into service.
Release of Prisoners of War.

Washington,June 6.--There are now remaining only four Secession prisoners at the Washington Navy-Yard, who are held under the order of General Mansfield. Thirty-five of them, including the cavalry privates captured at Alexandria, were this morning discharged on their taking the oath of allegiance.
They said in their letter that they wished to give up their profession and retire to private life.

Military Movements.Washington,June 6.--Military matters today have been conducted with more than usual caution.
Rumors of contemplated movements by Federal forces on Fairfax Court-House, Manassas Junction and Harper's Ferry are still prevalent, but reliable information is unattainable.
Affairs at Alexandria.Alexandria,June 6.--An attack was apprehended last night in some quarters, and the necessary precautions were taken, but the town has been very quiet.
The northeast storm still continues here.--The weather is quite cool.
The projected publication of a newspaper here by the soldiers has been prevented by the order of the Provost Marshal.

Release of Captain Ball and his Men.Alexandria,June 6.--Captain Ball, who was captured with his command at the taking of Alexandria, has received a pass to go outside the lines, in order to bring his family to Washington.
It is thought that his account of the good treatment he has received while a prisoner at Washington will have an influence on the Secessionists.
His oath was not merely a parole, but one of allegiance.
All thirty-five of his men took the same cath in Washington this morning.

The McDonald Habeas Corpus Case.St.
Louis, June 6. --The Republican says that McDonald will be produced to-day in the U. S. District Court, at Springfield, under a writ of habeas corpus issued by the Judge of that Court on Monday last.
A Young Lawyer of Baltimore Shot Dead at Williamsport.

Hagerstown, Md.,June 6.--Clinton Rench, a young lawyer from Baltimore, and nephew of William Price, Esq., was shot dead in Williamsport yesterday.
He was ordered to leave the town on account of his strong sympathy with the South, and when about leaving he gave expression to some language to the crowd which was deemed offensive by them, whereupon the men set to stoning him. Mr. Rench turned his horse toward the crowd, when a man leaped forward, and seizing the bridle, refused to let him go. Mr. Rench then drew his revolver and fired twice without effect at the man holding his horse, whereupon the crowd fired upon Mr. Rench and shot him dead from his horse.
Mr. R. Was a son of one of our most respectable and wealthy citizens, and for several years has practiced law in Baltimore.
The intelligence of his death created much excitement in this place.
Affairs in Louisville and Memphis.

Louisville, Ky.,June 5.--The Bulletin says that Col. Anderson feels sure that no troops are coming here, no interference from Tennessee respecting railroad matters being anticipated, and that the Nashville and Louisville Railroad will obey the orders of the Federal Government.

The Memphis Argus, of the 3d inst., says the boat-owners and captains of that city have recommended to the military authorities not to allow boats owned North, or by Northern sympathizers, to run in Southern waters.
Federal Troops Going to Calre.

St. Louis,June 5. --Col. McArthur's 12th Illinois Regiment, from Caseyville, embarked at East St. Louis last night on board the steamer Louisiana, for Cairo.
Col. Crook's Regiment also left town last night for the same destination.
It is understood that four regiments from Iowa and others from Wiscon-
sin, and still others from Chicago, bound South ward, are leaving to rendezvous at Cairo.

A Secession Camp Dispersed by Federal Troops in Kentucky.Cairo, Illinois,June 7.--A Secession Camp at Ellicott's Mills, in Kentucky, ten miles distant from this place, has been dispersed by two companies sent thither by General Prentiss. Colonel Wickliffe protested against the act as an invasion of the soil of Kentucky, to which General Prentiss said in reply that the act had been prompted by a letter claiming protection for the Union men there.
He declared his intention to send troops wherever needed for the protection of loyal citizens.
The Captured Whalers.

Louisville,June 6.--The Captains of the brigs John Adams and Panama, and schooner Mermaid, captured off the mouth of the Mississippi by privateers, passed through here to-day, bound eastward.
They represent that they knew nothing of letters of marque having been issued, and when the privateers approached supposed them to be pilots.
New Hampshire Legislature.

Concord, N. H., June 6.--Gov. Berry delivered his message to the Legislature to-day.
He calls immediate attention to measures that shall aid the General Government in resisting the rebellion against our institutions, and trusts that New Hampshire will be behind none of her other sister States in the appropriation of men and money for the purpose.
He recommends the organization of at least one regiment for every county in the State, to be thoroughly drilled and equipped for service at the call of the Legislature.
Secession Treated as a Nullity.
Washington,June 7.--The President has recognized Miguel Zaragosa as Consul for Mexico at San Antonio, Texas, thus continuing the policy of treating secession as a nullity.

Thomas B. Arden, of New York, has been appointed Paymaster of the Army.
Also, A. D. Stewart to fill a vacancy.
Affairs at Frederick — Exciting Reports.

Frederick, Md.,June 7.--This city was in a ferment last night.
It is certainly environed by dangers without and within.

The latest threats against the peace, and an appeal to the vigilance of its Home Guard, or the really startling if true reports — based, it is said, upon the statement of a refugee from Virginia, who overheard two Virginia Colonels discussing the diabolical plot in the cars — that a plan had been arranged by a force of Virginians to seize the person of Gov. Hicks, and certain members of the Assembly, including perhaps the eloquent "Farmer Linganore," and to bear them off to a place of security in that State.

The object of this highly improbable plot is said to be the transfer of the Gubernatorial powers into the hands of Speaker Brooke of the Senate, and the consequent precipitation of Maryland into the embraces of the Confederates.
Absurd as this story is, it appears to be really believed by many good citizens; and the utmost care has been taken to defeat its purposes.
A company of riflemen were detained, I hear, to guard the Dill House, at which the Governor is stopping.
Federal Troops En Route for New Mexico.
St. Louis,June 7.--A battalion of Federal troops from Carlisle barracks, destined for New Mexico, arrived here yesterday, and proceeded westward by the Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroad.
Insurance.
New York,June 7.--The insurance companies have advanced their war risks to five percent.

div3.head: An appeal to the Ministers of the different Denominations throughout the Confederate States, in behalf of a Collection proposed to be taken up on the 13th of June, to assist in defraying the expenses of the present war.
div3.p:
Fathers and Brethren: Behind an honored name we venture to address you. The momentous hour has come ! The death struggle for liberty has commenced ! The foot of the invader presses the soil of Virginia.
and even as we write, the blood of our sons and brothers is peradventure being poured out in defence of our altars and our homes — of all that we hold dear as men, as patriots, and as Christians ! Under such circumstances, all apology for thus addressing you is superfluous; it is enough that we feel the obligation of "helping every one his neighbor, and every one saying to his brother, 'be of good courage.'"

At the request of Congress, our honored President has called us to a day of Fasting and Prayer — a request with which, it is presumed, no one of us will fail to comply; but, besides this solemn, united and hearty appeal to the Supreme Power of the Universe for his merciful favor and protection, we beg to suggest, in all humility, whether it be not possible to make this coming occasion the opportunity of still further aiding our country in this, the crisis of her destiny, by contributing of our substance for the support of our brethren in arms ? Need we be reminded that the expense of transporting large bodies of troops, is in itself a heavy item of the war; and that it is a matter of the utmost moment that the treasury of Confederate States should know no lack at such a time as this ? It is respectfully proposed, therefore, to all whom this plea may come, that collections may be taken up on the 13th day of June, wherever two or three are gathered together, and this whether in camp or church; and if not on that day, then upon the best opportunity — that these moneys be immediately remitted to the Governors of the respective States, to be by them forwarded to the Hon. Mr. Memminger, Secretary of the Treasury, who shall duly receipt for the same.

In the name, the, of the just and holy cause to which the exigencies of the times have summoned us — in the name of the gallant States who are making a common stand against a blind and crushing despotism — a stand for constitutional liberty — a stand for the principles of 76--will you permit one who serves with you in the Gospel to entreat you to remember your country's need on that day of fasting and prayer, and to let your alms and your prayers go up together as a memorial before God?
Remember, beloved Christian men, that a million to-day may count more than millions to-morrow; and that what we do in this matter should not only be done with all our might, but be done quickly.

We appeal, then, to all who shall conduct devotional services upon that day, to allow an opportunity, at least, for the free-will offering of every one "whose heart may be stirred up." We appeal, moreover, to our noble and patriotic Governors, in any way they may think proper, to give this plea a friendly welcome.
We appeal to all editors to lend it the aid of their eloquent pens, for without their aid in this moment of time we can do nothing.
We finally appeal to all whose hearts throb for liberty, to help — help now — and remember that our country calls to-day.

p.q:
"Let God arise — let his enemies be scattered.
As smoke is driven a way, so drive them away; as wax melteth before the fire, so let the wicked perish at the presence of God."

head.hi: Three men sentenced to be hung.

div3.p:
--On Monday, Samuel Collins, alias Sabatteti, Louis Featherstone and John Dunleary, three of the crew of the ship General Parkhill, were sentenced by Chief Justice Nelson, of the United States Circuit Court in New York, to be hung in the city prison-yard on Friday, the 26th of July, for the murder of George W. Pyke, the master of the ship.
The crime was committed on the high seas on the 25th of February last, while the ship was bound from Liverpool to Charleston, S. C.--After their conviction the prisoners declared that the General Parkhill was a secession ship, and that Captain Pyke had a secession flag on board, which was ready for use at any time.
The district attorney stated that the evidence had shown no such facts, and read to them a statement of the bloody nature of the murder they had committed, as also the murderous attack upon the mate, they supposing that they had also dispatched him; how they had sharpened their knives on an iron railing preparatory to the murder, and recapitulated the number and character of the wounds they inflicted.
All of which the prisoners listened to apparently unmoved.--Since their conviction the ship has been seized for violating the blockade.

--At Cow Bayon, six miles from Walnut Bend, last Thursday, Wm. H. Robinson was shot by T. J. Dale, under the following circumstances: It appears that Robinson and Dale are partners in the management of a farm on which they lived, Robinson being the proprietor and Dale the operator.
Last Wednesday Dale thought he discovered some trace of improper intimacy between Robinson, who boarded in his house, and his wife.
So on Thursday morning he determined to test the matter, and for that purpose arose early and went ostensibly to put the servants to work, but instead of doing so, he shortly after returned to the house, and finding Robinson in bed with his wife, he shot him in the face, chest and arms, from which he shortly after died.
A stray shot penetrated the brain of Mrs. Dale, Killing her instantly.
At last accounts Dale was at large, no one feeling called upon to prosecute him.--Memphis Bulletin.

--Dr. Thomas C. Pettus, of Pettisville, Limestone co., Ala., writes us that there is a cave owned by Mrs. King, near Elkmont Springs, Giles county, Tenn., two or three miles from Elk river, from which the early settlers obtained saltpetre to make gunpowder; and another saltpetre cave near Redue's old mills, on Elk river, owned by John Davis.
Mr. D. C. B. Duniap brings us a message from Messrs. Wm. Ditto and H. Davidson, living near Lacy's Spring, Morgan county, that there are very rich saltpetre caves in Newsom's Sinks, very accessible, about fifteen miles from Whitesburg, near the road from Semorville to Blountsville, where Morgan, Marshall, and Blount corner, belonging to Mr. David Prince, who says the Confederate States may work them at pleasure.--Runisville (Ala.) Dem.

div3.head:
American Affairs in Europe.
tone of Lord Palmerston's organ — Views of a member of Parliament — Caunda and the balance of power — interesting Comments of the English press, &c.
div3.p:
Foreign files by the Australasian, at New York, show that the question of the American war continued to engage attention.
The letter of Cassius M. Clay, in the London Times, had been followed by another from Mr. Motley, the historian, who had at great length set forth his view of the American struggle, attributing all the trouble to the South.
Mr. Clay had found an antagonist in the person of Mr. De Leon, formerly American Consul in Egypt.
Mr. De Leon writes to the Times controverting the points set up by the Kentuckian.

The tone of the Palmerston organs is decidedly favorable to the letter of marque plan of the Southern Confederacy.
Indeed it is now held by high commercial and legal authority in England, that its commissioned privateers may take prizes into any neutral port and keep them there until their condemnation is pronounced by its admiralty courts sitting in Charleston, New Orleans, Mobile or Savannah.
This judgment, if equitably rendered, will, it is alleged, be binding on British maritime courts.

The people of England are said to be averse to the privateering business, but Mr. Lindsay, M. P. who recently visited this country, in a speech to his constituents at Sunderland, advised France and England to step forward and proclaim the independence of the Southern Confederacy as the only means of allaying the thirst for blood which, he says, prevails at the North.
The London Morning Post, Lord Palmerston's organ, asserts that the Southern States were de facto independent at the moment.

Lord Palmerston says, through his London organ, the Post, that Canada will soon become the centre of commerce and emigration for the American continent, and that a domestic army is about to spring from the ground in Canada, not only able to protect the neutrality of the province, but to maintain that balance of power which the folly of Republican America has transferred to British North America.

div4.head: English mediation offered.
div4.p: [From the London Star — Radical.]

The war must end in an accommodation of some sort, however severe the struggle, however decisive the issue.
The South may be thoroughly defeated, but cannot be destroyed.
Surviving the conflict, she will be in a position to negotiate with her victors.
The more she is humiliated, the more she will be embittered.
On the other side there will be exhaustion, or at least weariness.
The conquerors will be divided, and the vanquished will find advocates for clemency among the claimants to the spoil.
Either secession must be permitted, or terms of reconciliation adjusted.
Even the victorious Republican North--the Free-Soiler and Abolitionists --may be glad at such a stage to accept the mediation we now urge them to invite.--They can have no nearer kinsmen, no truer friends than the Liberals of the mother country.
In the name of those men — in the name, at any rate, of Liberal principles, and of the liberal cause throughout the world — we beseech the New England communities, so nobly forward in the strife, to pause ere they irrevocably commit themselves to the chances of battle, and to trust the interests of liberty rather to the arbitration of its friends in Europe than of the blind and senseless sword.

div4.head: England and France must stand by the Union.
div4.p: [From the London Herald — Derbyite.]

The Governments of France and Great Britain are scarcely likely to differ on the policy to be adopted in the present crisis, and it is not improbable that this question has already been discussed by the two Cabinets.
The Emperor Napoleon resided for some time in the United States, and is fully competent to judge of the relative strength of the rival sections, and when M. Thouvenel declared that the maintenance of the Union is necessary for the interest of France, he doubtless spoke the sentiments of his master.
The Emperor Napoleon is opposed to disruption of the Union, and it is rumored that he has even gone so far as to offer aid to President Lincoln against the seceders.
We have no means of ascertaining what are the intentions of our own Government, or the individual opinions of any statesman in the Cabinet, but we do not believe it will conduce to the welfare of Great Britain for the two Powers to be at issue on this American question.
[From the London Globe]

Statesmen in Europe will probably form their judgment from their own observation.
and not from the manifestos of either party in a dispute which has attained the dimensions of civil war. An Union which requires to maintain it the calling out of an hundred thousand volunteers and upward — an increase of some twenty thousand in the regular army, and some eighteen thousand in the navy — cannot but appear to most European eyes an Union past praying or fighting for. We are at all events well convinced that "this Union," (as Mr. Seward terms it,) will not come out of the conflict just as it goes into it. If that conflict is ever so little exasperated or protracted, it must draw much altered conditions of reunion after it.* * * We do not think the present secession of North or South the result of any sort of misunderstanding, either on one side or the other.
But we think it a very strange misunderstanding of the real depth of its source, which permits parties to it to fancy for a moment that the close of the struggle can leave the organized ideas and interests engaged where they stood at its opening.
[From the London Times, May 23.

War to the knife — war, if necessary, pushed to absolute extermination, to the destruction of cities, the desolation of provinces, the letting loose of millions of negroes on their proprietors — these words furnish a brief abstract of the resolution at which the people and Government of the United States appear to have arrived.
Respective lenity is delegated to heaven, and Government and people alike breathe the language of massacre and destruction.
No potentate against whose sway the ancestral vassals of his house, who followed his forefathers to the Crusades, have risen in armed revolt, can feel more acutely the outrage to his sovereign rights than the imperious democracy of America, founded on the declaration that all men are free and equal, and that every man has a right to seek his well-being and happiness under whatever government he pleases.
